title: How to get started on writing my novel - Quora

response.answer_text: To write anything — a story, a report, or a book — you have to know why you are writing it. As a novelist, you have to hone in on the event that brings the story into being and why your reader should care. That why is the question at the heart of every novel. The Heart of Your NovelThe why is one of the first things readers look for when we pick up a story. We look for the why in those first pages and generally find it in the inciting incident of the story. No inciting incident, no clear reason for why we should keep reading, and agents, editors, and readers will simply stop reading. Why read Your First Fifteen Pages? Because you want to develop a solid foundation for your novel and move beyond the agent’s slush pile. Why read The Firm? Because we’ve all had the experience of something sounding too good to be true and we want to know if this is one of those times. Why read The Husband’s Secret? Because we all know someone who’s had a secret, they didn’t want revealed. Why read The Hunger Games? Because we’re curious about what it would be like to fight to the death and if we would have the wear-with-all to survive. Why read Harry Potter? Because we want to believe magic exists, and see good triumph over evil. Why read The Invention of Wings? Because we are still trying to wrap our heads around slavery, why it lasted for as long as it did, and what finally brought about its demise. There are a million other reasons why we read fiction. Here are just a few more — because we want to know what it is like to be a spy, fight for someone’s freedom, discover a treasure, change identities, fail and finally succeed, find true love, come back to life…the list goes on and on. The WHY of The Husband’s SecretFor many writers, the why of a story comes from a place of natural curiosity. Before Liane Moriarty wrote The Husband’s Secret, she stumbled upon an article about deathbed confessions ranging from a man who faked a picture of the Loch Ness monster, to a famous songwriter who plagiarized a hit song and lied about it for years. But the confession that “got me thinking” Moriarty writes, was the man who, after having a stroke, confessed to murdering his neighbor. The man didn’t die, but the secret he almost carried to the grave was out. That article planted the seed of an idea for her novel The Husband’s Secret, which is about “a deathbed confession, except he’s not dead. Years later, after his wife finds the letter, she faces an interesting ethical dilemma.”  Knowing the why of you story helps you decide where your story begins. In The Husband’s Secret, author Lianne Moriarty wanted to explore the idea of someone intending to keep a secret until they died, only to have it revealed sooner. The idea came from an article she read about deathbed secrets. Look at the WHY in the chart and you will see the word SECRET and REVEAL are repeated. That is where her story begins, with the revelation of a secret. HOW the secret is revealed is the inciting incident. Finding this explanation for the genesis of Moriarty’s story on the Kindle version of The Husband’s Secret was an unexpected gift. Unless we attend author readings or conferences or come across an article by someone savvy enough to ask “Where did you come up with the idea for your novel,” we aren’t often privy to the ways writers get their ideas. We seldom know where the germ of a novel comes from and how it goes from idea to fully formed book. Fortunately, in the case of Moriarty, we do. We know that she read an article on deathbed confessions and that ideas wriggled around in her subconscious until she began to layer characters, place, and complications on top of the original premise.  Photo by Dương Trần Quốc on Unsplash In The Husband’s Secret, the inciting incident is the discovery of the letter with “For my wife, Cecilia Fitzpatrick. To be opened only in the event of my death” written on it. From that point on, everything in the novel supports the finding of the envelope. The decision to open it or not open it. The decision to tell her husband, John Paul, she’d found the envelope. The opening of the envelope by Cecilia. The consequences that follow. Each character and that character’s actions, everything they do, all the complications, dilemmas, and decisions they face and make, tie directly back to finding the envelope. Or, they move the reader towards the final resolution — why John Paul wrote the letter in the first place. Strong plots build from the inciting incident to the ultimate resolution of the story. A great story takes us from a question — why did Cecilia’s husband write a letter to be opened only after his death? To the inciting incident — Cecilia finding the letter. To a stunning revelation at the end of the novel — which I won’t spoil for you! Every scene, character, action, complication, and plot twist in The Husband’s Secret leads us, like Hansel and Gretel’s breadcrumbs from the inciting incident to that revelation. Keeping Your Story on TrackKnowing your WHY and having a fully formed inciting incident at the beginning of your book also helps you keep the story on track as you write. If you find yourself writing a scene in chapter 12 of your book and you suddenly have no idea where you are going, go back to the inciting incident of the book and ask yourself, “Does this scene support the why?” If not, retrace your steps back until you see where the story diverged from your why or the inciting event. This is so important I will repeat it yet again. Every scene, every complication, every character, and every action ultimately needs to tie back to your why and the inciting incident. If you haven’t defined the why of your story and your inciting incident by the first fifteen pages, you’ll be stuck, wandering around in a writing desert and dragging your reader along with you. After a few disconnected scenes that move us further and further from the inciting incident, we start to wonder where the story is going and, we stop reading. Let’s run through a few more examples before you tackle the why and the inciting incident for your story. How the Pros Do ItThe Firm opens with a young lawyer, Mitch McDeere interviewing for his first job out of law school. The inciting incident comes on page 13. After hearing everything that Bendini, Lambert, & Locke, a small firm in Memphis, Tennessee is offering, Mitch’s wife Abby says, “I don’t understand Mitch. Why are they so generous?” And off the story goes! The theme is, if something is too good to be true it probably is. Everything in The Firm points to that theme and back to the question “Why is this small firm in Memphis (few people have heard of ) being so generous?” By the time Mitch figures out why, we are hooked! We keep reading to see how he will extricate himself and his career from the firm. The Martian opens with Mark Watley injured and left for dead on Mars. He must figure out a way to survive until the next team arrives on the planet in four years. He has enough food to last one year if he rations it. He can either give up and die or find a way to grow food and survive. After Watley explains his dilemma to us, and we see him moving from analysis to survival mode, we are on board. From that point on, everything in the novel is about Watley surviving until he is rescued. The Invention of Wings begins on Sarah Grimke’s eleventh birthday. For her birthday, Sarah’s mother presents her with the gift of a young slave girl Handful. Everything in Sarah rebels against accepting another human being as a gift and everything in the Invention of Wings points back to the internal struggle against slavery, and of being enslaved, lived through the characters of Sarah and Handful. The Hunger Games — Katniss prepares for the Reaping, a ceremony during which a representative from each district chooses two tributes to participate in an annual fight to the death called the Hunger Games. When the representative selects her sister Prim, Katniss steps in to take Prim’s place. Each action, decision, and complication is tied to Katniss’ promise to stay alive and return to her family. Now it’s your turn. What is the WHY of your story and what is the inciting incident? NEED HELP WITH YOUR BOOK? CLICK HERE! Sandra is the author of Your First Fifteen Pages: An agent’s guide to writing a novel editors will publish and readers will buy! can help you over come some of the pitfalls discussed in this article.

Well you have the essentials already. If you are stuck on how to get into the writing it may be due to the large quantity of words that you have to go through. I would suggest doing a little more planning. Here is the first page in my Excel planning document:  You will have enough information to fill in the first parts here. Some of the boxes are linked to formulae on other pages so I can keep track of several bits at once. So a working title, a basic premise and a setting. From what you have said you have these. The next bit is to choose a word count and rough amount of chapters. I usually go for 80,000 words for a novel and 40 chapters. When you stick that into this you will see the words per chapter go to 2000. Now this is a bit that helps out. I have another page that totals my writing and fills in the words written. The formula tells me the words left so I can see where I am. It is the chapters bit that helps. If you have 40 chapters you can divide your outline over the 40 sections. i start with the beginning one and the last one. I then stick in the ends of the acts about chapters 10, 20 and 30. I carry on doing this until I have small plans for each chapter. Often a sentence or two. I can then keep focused on that one chapter. if I follow my plan I know it will fit into the wider novel and I also won’t get overwhelmed. I can easily write 2000 words in an evening after work so it’s a good solid target. When you have the plan and have decided you are going to write X words for a chapter (these aren't set in stone, I have chapters hitting near 4000 and others barely 1000) you can then start writing that particular chapter. Well to write straight out you just grab the idea for that section and start writing what comes to mind. If it is your first time writing a novel or indeed fiction you may want to try free writing. (Free writing). This will often give you far more than you need and most of that will have to be set aside as irrelevant but it breaks you into the actual writing. Once you start typing or physically writing try and either hit a word count or a time limit. this will help you get enough words out that you can edit later. Often the first draft will be almost utter nonsense when you are starting out. After a while they get more coherent. What you are trying to do is get words down that you can edit later. Physically typing a novel can take a fair amount of time just for the mechanical process. Once you have the words of a story there you can edit them. Think of it this way. If you watch a film you can easily be critical of this or that in a film. You will know that a certain character shouldn't have done that at all. Now try and write the thing yourself with nothing to compare it to. It is a lot harder. So get that first draft written. When I'm in the flow of writing I will smash through near 5000 words. often I don’t even correct typos or basic spelling errors. Once I hit a block I will run a basic spell check. That means I read bits of the chapter. By the time that is done I have ideas for the next section. As your first draft will receive a heavy edit don’t worry too much about the first line or indeed any line or sentence. Stick to your plan so you hit all of the main plot points. I have a chapter or two that will have to be completely rewritten to make them interesting but I hit all of the main points in the plot. There is just too much exposition. I do have words there though. I know I have written something that isn't quite right. I have built up how I want the world to look as well. Most of that bit wont make it to the final draft but I will save it in a folder with background. What you eventually have is a lot of material to draw from in your edit. the trick here is that your writing isn't useless. As Jody Lebel has commented just writing for the sake of it doesn't mean anything will improve but your ability to physically type, and to some extent, the accuracy of your spelling and grammar. You need to have an idea what you are doing to form the story. To expand on my above point about chapters you need to know how scenes work to be able to make those self contained chapters. I mentioned splitting the book into 10 chapter acts. These acts can be split into scenes. What you are looking at is hitting the important points as you write even if you are going to do a heavy edit. The basic challenge and failure, or success, method can be of use here. When you write each chapter you want the characters to be doing things that advance the story. Personally I find listening to http://www.writingexcuses.com/ podcast helps me get these concepts in my head as I go about my day job. I have a better understanding of how to form a story. It has meant that even when I write something I know I will cut later I know it will have a use as background or a seed for another story. So to sum up. Break down your story into chapters. Have a vague idea what you want to achieve in that chapter. Then just write something that fills the word count while hitting the main points (these are the bits that form the story, plot hooks, challenges, failures and successes). As you go along you will get better at it and will require less editing at the end. If you still struggle try free writing. If those red lines are annoying you turn off spell check until you need it.

Things take time. If you wanted to fly a plane, what would you do? You'd find a ground school and take lessons. If you wanted to play the piano, what would you do? You'd find a piano teacher and take classes. What makes writing any different? The man on top of the mountain didn’t just fall there. I'm going to give you my stock answer that I give everyone who asks me this question. Most people will tell you to just start writing, and keep writing, but I don't agree. I'm going to tell you why, give you some good advice on how to learn the craft, and give you a place to send in some of your work when you're ready. It's not enough to just write every day if you don't know what you're doing. That just means days and weeks and months of useless writing. It's like not knowing how to knit so you just keep making loops with the yarn. You can't get better, you can't turn that into a scarf ... you have the desire, but you don't know how. In order to write stories that people want to read you will need to understand how to put one together. There is a definite pattern and rhythm to it. And there are certain expectations from the editors and publishing houses as to how your story is laid out. You will need a good imagination, one that can look at a situation and picture all sorts of different scenarios. You need to be able to ask 'what if' and come up with twists and lines that are new and fresh. You will need to be able to research things. For example I wrote a story set in Iran where there was a wedding. I had to research how the wedding would take place, the food, the customs, common Iranian names, clothing, etc. in order to write an interesting yet correct story. Take classes in writing; grammar and punctuation (very important... lots of self published books are swimming in glaring errors and typos), character building, dialogue, plotting, pacing, point of view (POV), inner and outer conflicts, subplots, scenes and sequels, genres, story boards, twists, chapter hooks, suspense, killer opening lines, and satisfying endings. If you're going to write sci-fi you will need to take classes in world building. Each genre of book has its own set of expectations from the reader that you will need to fulfill. For example a murder mystery must have clues for the reader to try and solve. A romance needs a happen ever after ending, known to writers as an HEA. A thriller needs fast pacing and danger. Where to find these classes? Local community colleges often offer writing classes. My local library has classes seasonally. Best of all there are hundreds of classes you can take on-line. They run about $25-$35 each and range from 2 to 4 weeks. Google on-line writing classes and you will get lots of sites. There are sites that offer expensive classes, so be careful. I’d recommend starting with a few less expensive ones to see if you really like writing and want to continue. IMO it is not necessary to have a degree or to take an expensive course to write well. Try SavvyAuthors. They have classes year round. You can join their site for free and get a discount on their classes. Read a lot. Get a feel for how a story is told; how it starts, how it progresses through the story to a satisfying end. See how your favorite author keeps you interested. I don't know your age, but when you can join some writing groups, even ones online. Oftentimes these groups offer lectures and classes in writing. They share their work and critique each other. Writing is an art, but it's a learned art. It is very satisfying to see your name on a story. It's doubly satisfying to hear people talk well about your work. It's even nicer to receive a check :). Write short stories (800 - 1500 words). The more you write, the better you will become. You will make new writer mistakes, we all did. But that's how you learn. I say start with short stories because they are, well short, and don't take years to complete like a novel does. You can share your stories with others and get feedback. Take the feedback and use what you feel is constructive for you and ignore the others. Some people don't give good feedback, or there is a motive behind their negative comments. You have to learn which ones to take and learn from and which ones to disregard. And when you are reading and critiquing other's stories, be kind, give good feedback, and find something positive to say to them. It's hard to hear harsh things about your writing. It's tough love. But it works when you get it and understand why the comment was made and you go and make your piece better because of it. Submitting to contests is another way to get good feedback because the judges are usually editors and agents who have their finger on the pulse of good writing that sells. Once you feel you have written a great short story, be brave and submit it to a magazine that publishes fiction in the genre you wrote. Don't worry about rejections. They will come. Oftentimes it's not because your story is not good, it's because the story doesn't fit their needs. They are running a business after all, and they pick the stories that they feel will best entertain their readers. All authors get rejections. It's part of the 'hunt'. Here’s a place to start submitting. Check out their guidelines carefully. FLASH FICTION ONLINEhttp://flashfictiononline.com/main/submission-guidelines/We publish stories from 500 to 1,000 words in length. They’re very short, but they are still stories. That means the best ones have strong, interesting characters, plots, and (to some extent, at least) settings. We’re not that concerned about genre. Many of us have a fondness for science fiction and fantasy, but we also like literary fiction; and in any case, great flash stories aren’t always easily classified. If you wrote it, and you love it, then submit it. No erotica, porn, graphic sex, or violence. Pays $60 per story.

Getting started. There are probably as many ways to get started as there are authors. But let me note a few ways. I almost always start with a scene or a chapter or some idea that I desperately want to write. I start building my ideas and plot structure from that base. I find writing that first scene gives me a chance to possibly get some of my main characters introduced, give them substance and description and allows me to feel like they are alive so I can freely start imagining them. I can imagine where they live, what they look like, how they act and what they do for a living. The scene I write might not find its way into the novel, but it is the time when I light my imagination on fire, fall in love with my characters and imagine ways to rip them asunder.Plotting, outline and story structure. While writing that burning itch scene might be useful, at some point you have to do an A, to B, to C, outline to give the story an overall story structure. A basic outline can be as simple as introduction, initial character interactions, subsequent character interactions, conflict, conflict resolution and conclusion.One plotting outline technique that is helpful is to start with an overall outline. Maybe a page or less. Then move into each major outline point and create smaller less significant outline points that expand the outline for potentially 10, 20 or 30 pages depending on complexity. Further, you need to start outlining the major and minor characters, adding details and potentially bit of back story or history for writing those characters. Its helpful to make a list with names, faces, body details, tics or peculiar actions. From that you can design conversations and interactions that give the story more life.Once the story is structured, the first editing process should begin. Is my plot wondering around on a tangent? Is my minor character contributing meaningfully to the story. Does my plot make sense? There are thousands of decisions to be made, and at this point none of them are wrong so longs as you are contributing to the overall story.Once the plot is finalized, then start the first draft by inserting prose into the outline. Write the story between the lines of the outline. The discipline of writing from A to B in your outline helps it follow your structure. In the imagination and first draft process you might learn more about your characters give them additional descriptions and breathe more life into your characters. You might change an interaction because it doesn’t work, but you need the discipline to keep notes of the changes and update the blown out — outline so you continue to keep the continuity in your story.Finish your first draft. It’s harder than it sounds. You might not like parts of what you wrote, but you can’t let this distract you from the overall task. Vomit on the page if needed, but bring your story to the end. I have a bad habit of wanting to edit what’s written while I’m still in drafting mode. Some editing is good, especially if you are not in love with what you are currently drafting, but the goal of the first draft is to complete the first draft. Good, bad or indifferent, you have a long way to go before the story is completely started.Once the first draft is finished, only redraft those parts that are burning a hole in your soul. Maybe you have a continuity issue and that’s bugging you, sort out and resolve what’s bothering while it’s fresh in your mind.First drafts are garbage. Let it sit for a while. Maybe work on another project, but get the first draft out of your mind and let it freshen up. A few months from now, you can re-read what was written (as opposed to what you think you have written) and you can see what you wrote with a fresh perspective. Once you can read what was actually written you are in a position to do a heavy edit.Heavy editing is hard but is necessary. If in doubt, cut, trim and phrase things more elegantly. Get rid of passive voice and insert clean and clear active verbs. Examine each scene or chapter and character. Examine each conversation, each description and ask yourself a series of hard questions. Does the scene make sense as written? Does the scene further the plot? Have I given the reader enough detail without bogging them down in unnecessary detail? Do the conversations flow smoothly? Do I know who is speaking and do I know why that character said what was said? What are the characters thinking? Is what they are thinking evident through what was written or does the thought deserve a short explanation? Does the thought further the plot. The heavy edit is the author’s time to tighten up the plot and the characters, trim away the fat and passive voices. A heavy edit done with love and care, should take twice as long as it took to write the first draft. One thought to keep in mind. “A scene or a story should be like a woman’s skirt. Long enough to cover what’s necessary, but short enough to grab and keep my attention.”After a heavy edit has been done to the best of your ability, I’d consider your novel to be started. There are several additional steps that are needed to take your novel from its infancy to publishable material. I won’t belabor those points in detail except to say finishing your story is harder than anything I’ve described above. Line editing, copy editing, scene re-examination, plot re-examination, are topics that remain, and should be handled by someone with editing experience and expertise.

First off, do you have an idea? If not, write down all the little ideas you have that interest you. Possible plot points, premises, titles, things you care about, hypotheticals, dreams, genres, moral questions, whatever bugs you. Eventually, you’ll think of some ideas. Now try to think about a story that could happen with some of them. Thinking about an idea, do you start playing out possible plot points in your head, or do you get writer’s block? A good premise should be easy to turn into a story. Take the premise of Harry Potter: an orphan boy learns he’s a wizard and goes to wizard school. Even if you know nothing about Harry Potter, it’s easy to start imagining how the story goes. Your first thoughts might be too cliche, but you know you can make the plot work. On the other hand, you might think of a cool idea, like a boy with a lightning scar, but you have no idea what else happens in the story. It’s a good idea, and you should save it for later, but it’s not the premise. Eventually, you’ll find a story in one of your ideas, or you’ll think of a story by combining a few of them together. You can always bounce ideas off a friend if you get frustrated. Now you have an idea. Spend an hour thinking about it in your head, a few possible approaches and random scenes or characters. Now write - but don’t immediately write the novel. Write down information about the novel. This is how you get the first words on a page. Write down what’s going to happen, who the characters will be, what the themes will be. This doesn’t need to be extensive. You can have big gaps. But make sure you get at least a page or two. Every writer’s different, but I’d recommend figuring out these details in particular: 1) The names of all the most important characters, because saying “main character guy” gets tedious. If you get stuck, remember that Word and its equivalents will let you easily find and replace the name, so you can change it at any point in the writing process. 2) A one-line description of the premise, so you know exactly what you’re writing about. You can also have other, longer descriptions, but the more concise you can make this, the more coherent your story’s vision will probably be. You don’t have to work in every subplot and detail, just the overall elevator pitch you’ll need to think of later anyway. 3) The beginning, middle, and ending of your story, so you know the general structure of the plot. Also, make sure particularly interesting things happen around all three points. 4) Each of the main characters’ single greatest desire, single greatest belief, single greatest flaw, and single greatest need. Desire: the specific thing they want (to catch the killer, to become a movie star, the Iron Throne…) Belief: Their innermost value system (At his core, s/he’s a wo/man who believes in truth/honor/justice/love…) Flaw: their single greatest weakness, which they will either overcome or be destroyed by (Cowardice, arrogance, greed, toxic love, naivete, cynicism…) Need: What they need to become to overcome their flaw and either get the thing they desire or realize that it was never worth getting all along (Bravery, humility, generosity, the ability to let go, realism, hope…) These are all connected, which means they have to make sense together, but also that you can figure them out pretty much all at once. You don’t have to write these down as a checklist or anything, just make sure you understand what makes the character work on the inside. 5) The general arcs of the main characters, along with a few moral choices along the way. These need to be consistent. If, in the novel’s first half, the detective is so obsessed with solving a woman’s murder that he forgets to love his wife, it will be hard, if not impossible, to make the story’s second half be about the detective running for public office but having to overcome his racism. Those are two different stories, two different character arcs, and you’d be better off making that the sequel. Which doesn’t mean you can’t have your characters change drastically, or end up in very different circumstances, but there does need to be some kind of thread connecting them. Try and think of a few related moral choices that your character will face and make sure there’s some variety in what s/he chooses. By moral choice, I basically mean any time a character could pick between two or more options and what they choose says something about them. For major characters, they’ll ideally all make a few choices, but you only need two or three to build your story around at this point. In Casablanca, Rick used to be an idealist who helped people, now he’s refusing to help Ilsa, then he decides to help her but only to be with her, then he selflessly lets her go and embraces idealism once again. He makes contrasting, related moral choices, and those define his arc, and, ultimately, who he is as a person. That sounds like a lot, but it doesn’t have to be perfect. You can rewrite this all later, just get stuff on the page as quickly as possible. And you don’t have to do all of this, just do whatever is needed to understand the story you want to tell. Some people want to write long backstories for their characters, or samples of their dialogue. I don’t find that personally necessary, but this all to make you feel comfortable. But no matter what you do, if this is your first time writing a novel, write quickly. Like in tech, move fast and break things. I know a lot of aspiring writers. I have a degree in screenwriting, so the whole class was invested in this. Most of them still haven’t written any kind of long-form story outside what was done for the program. They all know the theory by heart, and they all outline, but they never stop outlining. You can’t get stuck coming up with ideas, constantly telling yourself you need to do more work on them. That’s not planning, that’s fear. My advice, give yourself three days for this step, then move on to the next stage. If it’s not perfect, you can still go back to it. And I don’t mean three eight-hour shifts. Eight hours total should be fine. Now write an outline. You might want to write a one-page outline or a five-page outline or something of that sort. I did that for some unpublished screenplays and it was fine, but I think redundant, and you might accidentally make your story too small or large for the space you want to fill. What I’ve found most useful is writing a scene-by-scene outline. A few lines’ summary of every scene in your novel, or even a one-line summary. Go to a new scene every time your story moves to a new place, time, or changes the characters involved, unless you know it’s going to be a lot of quick snippets (think a movie montage.) For reference, my novel ended up being about five pages per scene in the outline, so think about what length you want your book to be while you do this. (My scenes were pretty short, though, so keep that in mind.) Not all the scenes will be the same length, but they average out remarkably well, so after you write this, it’s easy to see if the emphasis in your story is different than you were expecting. This is the best time to make changes to your story, because it doesn’t take a lot of work. While you’re doing this, keep an eye on all the notes you wrote down. You want to make sure you stay on the story you want to tell, but also change it if you like a different idea more. Outline, but be flexible. And again, move fast and break things. Don’t take more than a week to write an outline, two if you’re busy. Then review the outline and make changes. You might want to show it to a friend for more objective feedback. Your friends aren’t necessarily correct and might just have different tastes than you, so don’t toss it out anything you really believe in, but take their words seriously and don’t take offense. Write new drafts of the outline, but only to fix your story’s flaws, not for the sake of it. I’d cap these revisions at a month. And once you like your story and don’t know what else to change, start writing. And if you’re still sorting a few details out, but the vast majority of it works, also start writing. If you’re not sure or not, also start writing. Seriously, start writing. You’re going to change your outline a lot, and that’s healthy. Stay flexible. I’d start at the beginning and write all the way through your novel, to maximize your flexibility, with one exception: I usually write my last page first, so that I know exactly where my story is going. I always change the last page when I finally get there, but it keeps the story focused. One caution about changing your story: Every time you introduce an element into your story, make sure you know its resolution. If you want to write with a lot of improvisation, that’s fantastic, and I do the same. But then immediately figure out where this new development is going after you’ve finished improvising, before you write past this point. Update your outline if it’s a big change, write down some notes if it’s a smaller one. This way, you don’t run into dead ends or introduce concepts or characters you can’t pay off later. If you get stuck, consult your outline. If that doesn’t help, write down more notes and details about the scenes you’re heading into, until you have a clear idea of what needs to happen. If, after writing it, you still think the scene is a little awkward, keep writing. You can revise later. If you get stuck on the little details, write out an an increasingly detailed outline of the scene you’re stuck on. (“Joe says he hates Nazis because of his dad’s death. The recruitment officer says he came to the right place. Joe signs up to fight.”) If a scene feels overwhelming, just write the dialogue and outlines of the physical actions. Then do another pass where you incorporate the dialogue into your prose. That way, you do both elements separately and can focus on one and then the other. I figured this out from screenwriting, where you’re only writing dialogue and the physical action. Another bonus of writing this way: It forces your conflict out of your character’s inner thoughts and into their words and actions. Essentially, it makes your book more cinematic. Just keep writing as often as you can. Don’t make an exact commitment, because if you say you’ll write five pages every day, you’ll just become dispirited the first time you only write four. But make sure you keep writing. It is more important to write often than to write a lot. If you only write a page a day, you’ll still finish a normal-sized novel in a year. If you can write ten pages in one day, that’s great, but if you only write three paragraphs every other day, that’s still progress, and you are now closer to your endgame than you were before. Do make sure you write consistently, and make sure writing is a priority, even if that seems a little selfish or irrational, or it will never get done. After you’ve reached the end of the book, save it for the millionth time in multiple places. Then go back through the book and fix up typos and clarify anything that’s really unclear. For your first revision, only fix the typos. Don’t make substantial changes. You will be emotional and might change something that’s better than you think, or which becomes important later and you’re forgetting right now. Take this time to think about your story and how it reads. Then beg your friends to read it. This is the single most dispiriting part of writing a novel. Not the feedback, just trying to get it. You only need two or three people to give you honest, considerate advice, but you’ll probably need to ask a dozen or more people to get this. It might not be the people you think, either. It might be that random friend from college. If your closest friends aren’t getting around to it, keep casting the net wider. Having someone you don’t know well give feedback can even be an advantage, because they experience the novel without too much information about you coloring their perceptions. Essentially, they’re closer to the normal person who’ll be reading your book after it’s released. After you get feedback, think about it for a week and then make revisions. See if you can change small stuff before you change big stuff. Sometimes, just adding or removing a line can completely change how a scene feels to the reader, even when they’d seemingly hated the whole sequence. If a character is unlikable, first try seeing if you can clarify the character a bit or add in a sympathetic moment before tossing everything out. If you wrote a strong outline, you probably won’t need to change major structural elements to the story, and if you really knew who your characters are, both on the surface and in their soul, you shouldn’t need to rewrite their conflicts too much That’s why both those elements are so important to plan ahead of time, because plot and character are the hardest elements of your story to change after your first draft. They’re too fundamental to every page. You may need a lot of revisions. Make sure you save every change. This is the point when you should be most cautious about moving fast, because your book will be very emotional to you and you might easily underestimate or overestimate your work’s quality. I can’t tell you how long this will take or when it’s time to stop, but you do need to make sure you stop eventually. If people start reacting to your novel like it’s a finished work instead of suggesting improvements, that’s a good sign it’s finished. They will probably still suggest a few things, because that’s what you asked them to do, but they’ll become smaller, something they add after thinking about it. Throughout the entire writing process, keep taking notes every time you think of an idea related to the novel, no matter how minor. A line, a concern, a character name that seems cool even though you don’t know who it’s for. Make sure these notes are immediately accessible on both your phone and whatever computer you use to write. I make an email chain for every story, so that I can write down ideas as soon as they occur to me, and then I can quickly find them on my computer while writing. Also, at any time, if you come up with a scene in extended detail, just write the scene. Even if you don’t know the rest of the story, just write it. You’ll probably have to change it, and it might not fit at all, but you’ll thank yourself later for writing it down, because you will forget the details later. On that note, save everything. If you make major changes to the text you’ve already written, be it your notes, outline, or manuscript, save it as a new file so you still have the old one. (I just write “D1,” “D2,” etc. for each successive draft.) Eventually, you’ll change your mind and need something you would have otherwise deleted. Hopefully, that helps. There’s a lot of good books out there on story structure and character development by people like John Truby, Laurie Hutzler, and Dara Marks. None of them need to be taken as gospel, but they’re all helpful if you feel unprepared. Finally, I learned all this through my own writing, and I recently published a novel for the first time, And One Day My Stars Will Burn. Please do check it out if you have the chance…

Don't start writing until you've got your idea nice and tight in one sentence - packing a mean ironic punch. No really, I wouldn't if I were you. I have, but when you start flabby, it's like loosely packed clay on the potter's wheel. You press the pedal and you've got shit flying in all directions. I won't let my writers at Kritikme start writing until we know we have a solid, hard-working, great - and yes - that means commercially viable idea for a story. You leave The Classic Course with wonderment and irony locked and locked into your story idea. You start The Ninety Day Novel course with seven days to get this tight. Honestly, a great idea can take years, so this is the hardest work you'll do on the course. Delivering the content of a novel is easy, once you've got an idea you can't wait to write and then you can allow yourself this Peter Pan moment: “How clever I am!” he crowed rapturously, “oh, the cleverness of me!” It is humiliating to have to confess that this conceit of Peter was one of his most fascinating qualities. To put it with brutal frankness, there never was a cockier boy. (JM Barrie: Peter Pan and Wendy 1911) What do I mean by irony? Well, it's not 'rain on your wedding day'. That's just bad luck. What's ironic about Alanis Morrissette's song is that it's not ironic. the expression of one's meaning by using language that normally signifies the opposite, a state of affairs or an event that seems deliberately contrary to what one expects and is often wryly amusing as a result.a literary technique, originally used in Greek tragedy, by which the full significance of a character's words or actions is clear to the audience or reader although unknown to the character.One notion in conflict with another SPRINGLOADS the idea and traps the reader inside the confection of your fiction, rattling between point and counterpoint immediately. The result is the reader goes - WHAT! And that's how we want to keep them from start to finish of their reading experience. Policeman turns to crimeTeacher learns lesson from students.Man who doesn't like women, becomes a woman,for the love of a woman.If you can load your title with irony too, you're ahead of the game and can leave the elevator without a pitch. I like 'Judge on Trial' by Ivan Klima, and 'Beware of Pity' by Stefan Zweig. 'The Good Soldier' is good when you know the context. Titles that defy our expectations like 'Love In the Time of Cholera' work well. After two limp novels, I worked hard to make sure my third hit the mark and loaded my title with irony 'Becoming Strangers' with the idea being that a dying man found new life. The irony is stowed in the FLAW which sets up the novel (you can find out more about the big story structure on the course - see the Kritikme Five F's) and in a children's classic this is a COSMIC FLAW which delivers 'cosmic irony' the disparity between what humans desire and what the world actually serves them. Mostly, in the classics, this is the chosen kid who's an orphan. This is an irony of fate. No one's fault. The big funny not so haha from on high. Beethoven - a great composer - loses his hearing. Ouch. Because a novel is a moral journey, as well as all kinds of other adventures, a cosmic flaw, a twist of fate, locks in sympathy and hope and at the end of the day a reader reads on hope. So, it's pretty simple. Your idea should ring clear as a bell. Make sure you're packing irony at the outset. In my bluffer's visual above, the balloon of the idea rises, with the pin that pricks it underneath - poised to make you and your comfortable ideas, dear reader, go POP! Good luck, and if you want to make sure you’re on track, come find me and I’ll help you at Kritikme.

There are as many ways to begin writing a novel as there are authors, what works for me, more than likely won’t work for you. If this is your first, then here is some solid advice. I am sure you have a rough outline of what you want to write inside your head. Don’t try and write the hook straight from the start, it is far easier to do once you have finished your first novel. Trying to write that hook can be a bit of a challenge, especially if you aren't a professional writer. So wait until you have built up your skills; it will come easier. Keep a note of your characters as you create them and their relationships to each other. Do it in a separate notebook. Do it on a pc or electronic notebook of some kind, ie laptop, netbook, notebook. I use a netbook, it makes it easier to research something at the drop of a hat. Everything these days is submitted electronically, this makes it easier in the long run. At this point I would go to Createspace and create an account; download one of their formatted templates, this will save you so much grief later on. Once you start, DO NOT go back over each chapter as you create them. Once you start, do not stop. I will let you into a little secret. Unless you are a professional write, most of what you first write will be a load of crap. If you go back and start playing with stuff, you will quickly realise how bad it is, and become disheartened. I have talked to so many people who have simply given up after a half dozen chapters. What they did not realise is that it is a process. As you write you begin to create pathways in your mind that did not exist before. How do you write this, how do you describe that etc. each time you solve a problem you create a new pathway that you can revisit at any time. As you progress through the novel, and create these pathways, your writing will become tighter and tighter. When you have finished the novel, sit it down for a couple of weeks, then sit down and read it as you would any other book. Send it to your kindle if you have one. Just send it to your kindle email address and write convert in the subject line. This will send a kindle converted copy straight to yourself. If you prefer paperback, you have a number of options. You can upload it to Amazon or Createspace. If you create an Amazon author account and create a paperback version, you can have one sent to you before you publish it. I prefer Createspace. If you order from Amazon, then it will be there in a few days. You have to pay extra for that with Createspace, or you will wait for a few weeks before you get a copy. The hardest part of writing your first novel is reaching the end. The hard work begins once you write the end. You will have to be honest with your self at this stage, and may well have to rewrite large chunks, I know I had to. Once you have done all that, write some kind of descriptive hook, it should be quite easy by that stage. A couple of things to note. As your skills develop, you may well find the novel turning in a different direction to what you first imagined it. Holding to hard onto an outline, or beginning, middle, end, will result in failure. It is taking a different direction, because you are developing your skills. Some can do it, but not that many. You may start out like that, but may well find yourself flying by the seat of your pants towards the end. If you find yourself in this situation, then ease up on your hard stance, let it become fluid in your mind. Well that is quite a bit to be getting on with. If you start and get stuck, give me a shout.
