response.answer_text: Sit. Write. Maybe it will look good and you will keep going. Maybe it will suck and you will come up with another approach. Maybe (most likely) you will not be happy with it, but will see the seeds of something you can edit and/or rewrite later, It is possible to overthink this process. It is possible to get so obsessed with preparation that it kills your creativity and confidence. Is your outline good enough? Is your third act sixth phase reverse rising tension ironic undertone done right? Have you got every beat of your first chapter brokem down into perfect triads of action/reaction/(I don’t even remember what the third one is supposed to be)? You will never learn to write until you put words on paper, Mind you, that may not be *enough*. You may write 50 pages and then decide you really need to study up on dialogue. Or get ideas for plot structure, or whatever. But for now just friggin’ WRITE. Pick a scene you are dying to put on paper and don’t worry about what comes before or after it. Feel what it is like to bring that scene to life. Experience your characters, See what your strengths and weaknesses—and needs—are. Then research the things you feel you need to research. Maybe you’ll need lots of books to help you, Maybe you won’t, I’ve made my living as a novelist for 30 years and I never read a book about how to write before I started. I suspect that if I had been encouraged to do as much prep before writing as you are being advised here, my first novel would still not be written. Seriously. Sometimes I think we need a new verb in the English language , ”to quora”, meaning “to prepare for an action so thoroughly that you never actually do it”. I do agree with one piece of advice given here. You should not start with a novel, but with short stories, Why? Because a first novel is an investment of months of effort, probably years, with an infinitesmally small chance of success. The sheer magnitude of the task can get overwhelming. Even a professional author needs major discipline to approach a project that large, and laser keen focus to make it successful. So write a short story first. Submit it somewhere. If it fails, get feedback and learn to write better. Work on a project where if you don’t have perfect discipline, you can still succeed. Make your mistakes in a format that you have not invested years of hope and energy in, so you learn from your mistakes without your spirit being crushed, and can grow as a writer. Then, when you are ready artistically and emotionally, go for the big one. (As a side note, you get paid for any stories you sell, so there’s an immediate benefit to this plan) Stop asking how to write, and write.

Before you begin writing a novel, you should have a decent vocabulary and be able to use the words you learn and be able to say them in as many different ways as possible so as to not feel as though you are repeating yourself and bore your readers. A thesaurus is one good resource to have, as it lists synonyms you can memorise for when you want to enrich the volume of vocabulary found in your novel. Do not worry about making grammar mistakes or typos. When learning new words, try to apply them in daily conversations so that each new word that you learn becomes second nature. Chances are that you will misapply some words when they are new to you, or if you rarely use them. Either way, do not let that discourage you from using them. Leaving your comfort zone and expanding on your vocabulary by allowing some mistakes to be made is better than not using these words at all. If you are new to creative writing, I suggest writing some fan fiction first, in order to know how characters interact and develop. Look for shows or movies you are familiar with and write your own stories about the characters. I spent a good ten years of my life writing plenty of fan fiction in different genres before I even seriously considered writing my own original stories with actual character development. In the same way that drawers will tell you that they cannot learn to draw their own original drawings until they have acquired the knowledge to do so from drawing characters from other creators, a writer is going to have a lot of difficulty writing a new story with original characters if they don’t even know what makes a story/character good or bad and how a story should be structured. Once you have a lot of experience writing creatively, start to write down characters you come up with by listing everything you know about them. Write down what their age is; what their physical appearance is; what their beliefs are; what their strengths and weaknesses are; what their purpose and goals are; who they know and like/dislike; what types of food they like to eat; what is their employment; what is their dress style; what activities are they known for doing; what their background story is etc.. Even if such information won’t be mentioned specifically in the novel you are writing, it gives you a good reference point to know what your characters would be doing in a certain situation and how they would react to that. It is impossible to write about a character in your story when you know literally nothing about them. In addition, your potential readers may want to know more about your characters in order to relate to them more. Having a detailed profile about your characters (including your secondary characters) is going to receive far more positive feedback than a wooden dialogue and performance. Write as much as you can all day, every day. Even if there is a day when you might decide that you’re not in the mood to be writing your creative writing project, jot down some notes about random things or even type on your e-mail. It is better to be writing something, even if the quality is poor and unrelated to your work, than nothing at all. If you are only planning on writing one novel, then this next piece of advice does not apply to you; but if you aspire to write as many novels as possible, you should switch back and forth from one novel to the next on a regular basis, as you won’t get bored so easily when you have another writing option if the first one starts to wear you down. Even if you can’t think of anything good to describe a scene or dialogue in your story, write it down anyway and move on until you either think of something, or you complete the first draft. Spending too much time trying to think of the perfect sentence on your first draft is likely to create a tedious process more unbearable than you would be able to handle, and you are that much more likely to just quit altogether. There is no point in making your first draft perfect, because odds are that by the time your first draft is completed, something else will come to mind which would make the story that much better, and that would require you to effectively rewrite your entire first draft, anyway. Most serious novelists will rewrite their entire story three or four (or more) times before they find a concept to their story which they attach themselves to. Even the first draft of Empire Strikes Back had a very different story line and outcome compared to the finalised version that was eventually released. Having perfect grammar skills as a writer is inconsequential, as there are professional editors available if it matters that much to you to be a perfectionist (note, even so-called professional editors make mistakes). Besides, if you go with the traditional publishing route, your writing is going to be getting proofread by others, anyway. On the other hand, since this is creative writing, you can probably even get away with certain grammar typos and mistakes which wouldn’t be the case if you were writing a non-fiction research textbook by claiming that your character has a unique way of speaking, or that something in the book cannot be properly explained with real world vocabulary (such as J.R. Tolkien using Elvish instead of Elfish). Charles Dickens and even Theodor Seuss Geisel (Dr. Seuss) were known for their grammar errors and mistakes, even though they were often times deliberate. Jane Austen and a few others also had difficulty with grammar, so it is not the end of the world if you have some mistakes here and there. Remember: writing is a lot like music in that the average reader is very unlikely to pick up on mistakes that tend to be noticed by an experienced reader/writer. If your creative writing is based on real-world events, educating yourself in geography, politics, history, languages and science can help you be able to include required facts and information needed to advance your story into the book without feeling foolish if a reader calls you out later on your mistake. Learning about different topics can also help inspire you to write about events based on real life events and/or personal experiences that you might otherwise not have thought about and have something to write down and avoid writer’s block. In the end, most readers actually like “fictional” stories that could be true, no matter how implausible the story might be. Indicating that some of your ideas come from events that happened in our world has a far better chance to intrigue your readers than something made up out of thin air which the reader cannot relate to. Before you make a video game, you should know some coding and other software. Before playing music, you should know how an instrument works. If you want to be a culinary chef, you need to know how to handle kitchen utensils and how to operate an oven, stove and microwave. The same is true for writing novels. How can you write a novel if you don’t truly know what a novel looks like or how it functions? Just knowing that a novel has paragraphs, words and grammar is not good enough. You need to also know how to present those paragraphs, words and grammar; and to be quite frank: there is no magic formula for that. Each novelist has their own style of writing in the same way that each drawer, programmer, musician or chef has their own style of drawing, programming, performing and cooking. If you have not read up on the works of other novelists, you should do so. Even comparing books of random authors whose names you may or may not know is just as efficient. In fact, it is highly recommended that you not limit your readings to just mere classics and/or famous authors. If you really want to get a wide range of approaches to writing a novel, reading the works of less known writers might give you ideas that you otherwise may not have thought of. Keep in mind as well, that every famous author today was an unknown at some point, and if the unknown authors you read about while they are unknown become famous one day, then you can brag about how you knew about this author before everybody else did. How famous they are does not suddenly mean that they are unworthy of your time. Something to keep in note: do not limit yourself to just reading good books that receive high reviews. In fact, you should probably even read some bad books as well. When you read these “bad” books, you should ask yourself why this book is bad, and what could have been done to improve it. In the event that you either don’t have the time or money to write a book, you could always hire a ghostwriter to write the actual book, after you’ve given them the ideas. Personally, I wouldn’t recommend this route, as a ghostwriter is very unlikely to come back with a style and approach that you find truly satisfying (since only you really know what your book is about) and this may cause far more frustration compared to just writing the book yourself. Besides, how can you really say that YOU wrote the book, when at best the only thing you did was give somebody else the ideas? When figuring out a plot to your story, you should write down every scene you can think of off the top of your head and write them down on a list. Even if the idea is not great and is unlikely to make it into the final draft, you should do it anyway. When brainstorming for scenes, there are no bad ideas, only plausible one. After you have your characters and story fleshed out, you need to figure out a way to have your characters go from one scene to the next. Connecting the dots gives you a literary pathway to know how to overcome any and all obstacles that may be encountered on the way. If a scene becomes impossible to add without ruining the rest of the story, you are better off to modify it or delete it outright. It is better to have one lost scene than an entire story’s quality deteriorating as a result. When I write creative writing stories, I tend to develop each story in six different drafts: The Sketch DraftThe Rough DraftThe Filler DraftThe Dialogue DraftThe Grammar DraftThe Polished DraftThe Sketch Draft The first step of the physical writing process of any story, in my opinion, is called the Sketch Draft. This is the draft where you know the fundamentals of your story. You know what the beginning, middle and end are (even if this may change later), as well as your main characters. In the same way a drawer does light sketches before creating a more detailed drawing, a writer should have an idea as to where their story is heading and how it will end. At this stage, the writer should have several questions and answers already figured out. Some of these include, but are not necessarily limited to: Who are the characters in the story? Why are they in the story? What is their purpose? What are their goals? Why do they have such goals? What are their characteristics? What are their strengths and weaknesses? The author must also know how the story will end and be able to answer questions, such as: What is the solution to the story? What type of message am I trying to convey? How do I want my readers to feel? What genre is this? What type of people would be interested in this story? What are my reasons for writing this book? What kind of effect (if any) would it have on the lives of those reading my work? If you cannot even answer these questions, then it is going to be impossible to do the other stages and expect your work to be of the quality that would entail bragging rights. This would be like wanting to draw a cartoon character, but not knowing what the age, physical appearance and dress-style of your character is, or even knowing what kind of style you want, for that matter (Realistic, Manga, Simpsons, Disney?). The Rough Draft The Rough Draft, in my experience, has been the longest and most frustrating stage of writing a story for the simple fact that when writing the rough draft, you are still uncertain as to how you will approach the story and how your characters will interact and solve any problems they may face along their journey. It is also long, because it is the only stage that requires you (at least in theory) to write the book from beginning to end before proceeding to the next stage. How many words you write at this stage can vary from as few as 20,000 to as many as a million (or more) words. On the other hand, there is one positive aspect to the rough draft: the quality of your writing is not that important at this stage. While this does not imply that you should neglect your work altogether, it does mean that it is not the end of the world if you can’t think of a masterpiece description or dialogue right away. Rather, you ought to continue churning more words and advancing your story and leave such problems for later. Your morale will likely be sapped if you fret too much about such obscurities, as you won’t feel that you are progressing sufficiently enough. The Filler Draft Any scenes that you skipped, forgot or only thought about later can now be added into your rough draft at the Filler Draft stage of development. See this as more of a patch-up for rough drafts. Perhaps you later realised that there was a scene you wanted to add and forgot. It is also quite probable that a good scene or interaction that could improve your story was only thought about later in the Rough Draft stage. Or if might be a simple matter of you choosing to skip a scene because you did not have a solution at the time for how to solve that scene and move on to the next. Regardless of the reason why certain scenes are missing from the rough draft: the Filler Draft is the best time to fix any plot holes you may have discovered or know about and wish to repair. While doing the Filler Draft, you should still start out reading from the beginning and reading until the end. Along the way, correct any spelling mistakes or grammar errors that you may have missed the first time around. Reading a story from beginning to end on the Filler Draft also makes it more likely that you will notice some inconsistencies with your story than if you only focus on new scenes that you want to include. Starting from the beginning and working your way back to the end also means that you may be inspired to add some new scenes which you otherwise may not have thought about. While the Filler Draft is also where you have the chance to correct the more obvious spelling/grammar errors, its purpose is ultimately to ensure that the story itself makes sense and that the development of both the plot and characters are as strong as can be. The Dialogue Draft The Dialogue Draft is similar to the Filler Draft, except that now, your primary focus is to either add or improve upon the dialogue and interactions of your characters. If a dialogue turned out cheesy, but you added it in there anyway because it was either the best you could muster, or it turns out to not be as great as you initially thought: you now have the opportunity to upgrade the dialogue aspects of your characters. How your characters interact is even more important than the actual description of your story for the simple reason being that speaking is more natural than describing things in words. While describing an event or place is good when it cannot reasonably be said by a character in your story, an author should also avoid relying too much on descriptions when it can be just as easily said by a character. There is a saying by many authors that goes along the lines of “show, don’t tell.” What this means is that you need to be able to tell a reader what is going on in the least direct way possible. For instance, if a character is scared, don’t bluntly say “the character was scared” as that does not leave much room for a reader to interpret what is happening, and it makes the reader feel as though you are telling them how they should be thinking. Not to mention, it feels cheap and wooden to be that direct. It would be like telling a joke to someone, and then you explain the joke while actually saying it. Below is a good example of what I mean:  It is also just as true if you are describing someone’s relationship. If you claim that somebody secretly hates/loves somebody, you don’t put it in a description by saying “she secretly loved her so-called nemesis, but she would not admit to it.” While this may be more forgivable in the rough draft stages when you are still trying to get everything sorted out, it needs to be cut out by this point of the writing process, and instead you need to have this shown in the actions/dialogues of your characters. This does not mean you have a character bluntly tell another character what they are thinking (unless this is their real personality) as this also cheapens the effect. Don’t go writing “I am jealous of this person because he is smarter than me.” Rather, you should make that same point by having the character say things which would be perceived as a form of jealousy in the real world without directly saying it. Having the character go behind their backs and possibly gossip about them or put their faces on a punching bag etc. all make for a far better message as to what a certain character thinks and feels. If anyone has ever heard/written down a court transcript, they would know that people in the real world don’t talk like they do in the creative world. In the real world, even so-called educated people are going to repeat words like “if,” “the,” etc. several times over in quick succession when they stutter or fail to think of something constructive to say. Words such as “uhhh” appear hundreds of times in an average court case, even though most people wouldn’t know how frequently they are actually saying it. Saying the grammatically wrong word in open dialogue is also a common occurrence, regardless of your education, setting or intelligence. On the other hand, if you were to have stuttering and/or poor grammar appear in dialogue in your creative writing stories, you are more likely to bore your readers, and the overall message and story might suffer as a result. The only times it should be permissible to have stuttering and dialogue errors in your story is if your character is nervous, uneducated or they simply don’t know how to express a certain situation or event. Even when such exceptions arise, the amount of times this type of dialogue should be used in a novel should be kept at a minimal, even if this is being done by a main character. The dialogue you add needs to be both interesting and believable. Does what is being said sound like something this particular character would say? If not, then you have to either give that line to another character whom would be a perfect match, or the dialogue needs to be modified to be compatible with that specific character. The Grammar Draft The fifth stage is the Grammar Draft. This is when your scenes, characters and dialogue have been mostly worked out and you just want to ensure that any typos or grammar mistakes you may have missed are finally corrected. Essentially, your goal at this point is to scavenge around your novel to find the less obvious errors. Needless to say, this should be a fairly straightforward process. If you are worried about grammar mistakes, find a proofreader/editor to help you out. Don’t lose too much sleep if some mistakes do occur. Chances are that if you had been looking for the obvious ones throughout the previous three stages (Rough, Filler and Dialogue Drafts) the mistakes are not that likely to be picked up by a casual reader, as they are going to be too busy immersing themselves in your story (assuming it is worthwhile for them to do so). I can’t even think of a book that isn’t without some sort of grammar/spelling mistake. If you later find yourself in a precarious situation of having published your book, only to later discover the mistakes when it is too late to correct them: You are in very good company and your mistakes are not as likely to stand out compared to that time when an entire edition of the Bible was publicly burned over a single typo. Wicked Bible - Wikipedia The Polished Draft The Polished Draft is the last stage of writing. At this point, you should just take a break that is long enough that the developmental process up until this sixth and final draft is not going to be fresh in your mind. After taking a break, ranging anywhere from mere days to over a year, you should read your story all over again from beginning to end. This time, however, you are now reading this book as if you were just a regular reader, as opposed to the author. When reading the book, you have to ask yourself whether the questions you had offered at the start of your writing journey have been satisfactorily fulfilled. For example: Do my characters resolve their goals? Does the story end in a way that it would give positive closure to the reader? Are all the answers brought up in the story answered? Are the characters likeable? Is the dialogue and description of the story interesting and original? Will the story influence readers in the way I intended? (emotional, political, spiritual etc.) Is there anything else I could have added to improve this story? When you are coming back after a prolonged period of time, you are more likely to be able to answer such questions honestly, as you are far less likely to become sentimentally attached to your work. Furthermore, it can be hard to know what your readers will see in your story when you are the writer, since the reader does not have your mindset. It is YOUR job to help translate your mindset to them. You can talk about a character as much as you want, but how is the reader supposed to appreciate that character if they don’t even know what they look like or what kind of personality they have? If you had answered ‘yes’ to the last question answered two paragraphs above, you may want to figure out what those improvements are and go back to fixing them. This may mean repeating the previous stages all over again. Nevertheless, with the possible exceptions that you are dying or someone is physically preventing you from continuing with your story, there is no reason you should choose to let your story’s potential be tarnished because you don’t have the motivation to honestly know when an improvement can be made and spend the time writing down these improvements. Later on, you might choose to take another break and read the story all over again. You might even do this several times over until you decide that it is good enough to finally show to the world. And once that happens, you can probably even go out and celebrate by eating out for a special occasion. CONCLUSION In conclusion, I should also add that another thing you have to do is to continue motivating yourself to write. Rather than seeing the process of writing as an obligation, you should see it as an opportunity. Even if the latter feeling does not do it for you, you should find other ways to motivate yourself. One solution is to tell yourself that if you write a certain number of words per day, you will reward yourself with a beverage or snack. Once you complete a chapter or a certain amount of overall words, you will take a day off writing and go eat at a restaurant etc.. The hardest part about writing is not the writing itself, it is the creativity that goes into writing. The former is just an inconvenience in comparison.

Forget all about attending courses and paying money to be a better writer. Everyone who has something to sell, to boost their own coffers, not yours, will tell you that the only way to be a better writer is to go on course X, or Y. They're richer, you're poorer and the rewards are variable. Ask yourself if Shakespeare, arguably the greatest writer in the English language, ever went on a 'How to Write Killer Plots' course. Without question, he learned his craft by reading, by having an imagination (his mother would read fantasy stories to him and his siblings every day) and by having the willpower to make something happen for himself. Your question, however, talks about how to start writing. Here's a list that is not the only way to do it, but it helped me. 1. Start writing your idea down. It will be rubbish and it's supposed to be at this stage.2. Circle any names that appear regularly - you just got some main characters.3. Circle the places in your story - you just got the landscape of your story.4. Underline who does what to whom - you just got some action.5. If you've written why they do it, you also just got some plot.6. Leave your story alone and make bread.7. Whilst making bread, you'll realise that although you have the ingredients, your bread will taste like cr** if you don't knead the dough. Now you're thinking like a writer. Grab a separate piece of paper for each of your characters, your places and your actions. Add some detail from your growing imagination. If some detail crosses over, grab that other piece of paper and add it to that. Whether it's two people meeting at the same event, or sharing the same mother, or sharing the same secret, add it to their sheet.8. Start to write your book - you don't have to start at the beginning, but here's an idea. Write your first sentence. This is your bread in a shop window. How it looks before tasting is how well it goes down. Don't pay anyone to learn this; go onto Amazon and find quality novels recently published. Click the link above the book's image and select 'Look inside' button. You just got access to the best authors' first lines (even first chapters) - how they chose to really nail their reader from the beginning. Once you have written this first sentence(and it can change) you have gone from being a researcher to a writer.9. Your most important job as a writer is not to write, but to not give up on writing.10. Don't give up on writing - just because it takes time.11. Don't give up on writing - just because it's hard, infuriating and has caused some writers to commit suicide.12. Your book will take at least a year to write - seriously. Don't think you can drum it out over the Summer break. Your bread won't bake in 6 minutes. You need to keep looking in the oven and making sure it's nicely browned. But if you stand around staring at it, you'll get bored. Walk away from it every now and then - do something else - come back to it and make sure it's getting along OK. Similarly, don't leave it too long, or it will burn.0. Zero, not because thirteen is supposed to be unlucky, but because you should have been doing this from day 0...work out who your audience is and write for them. Market your book before it's written. This, above all other things, will determine whether you book takes on a life of its own and can be tasted, and liked, by others. 14. Read. For pleasure, not for 'research', but you'll soon discover that the dynamics of others' writing bleeds into your own (whether good or bad - so choose wisely).15. Don't give up on writing.

Practice your story-telling. Start with a short tale you think is funny or interesting or surprising in some way. Imagine how you would tell that story to a friend at a party. How do you grab the listener's interest? How do you introduce the characters without getting bogged down in back-story? How do you pace it and make it more dramatic (dialogue? action?), so they don't try to wander off to get a drink? How do you hint at what may be revealed without giving away the ending? Then do your best to write that down. Then, imagine the same story in your head as a television show or a movie. Start with something suspenseful or particularly interesting to grab attention and propel the reader/viewer to the next sentence or keep them from changing channels at the commercial break. Stay with one character's point-of-view to make things easy to follow and describe what that person sees, hears, feels, and thinks. Revise what you've written already to give it this more cinematic feel. Novels are big and can be complex, so start with a simpler story or maybe a scene from what you imagine as your larger work. Once you've written it. Set it aside for at least a few days, then reread it. If anything seems clunky or confusing, change it. Repeat until you are satisfied, then ask a friend (one who is honest and willing to be candid) or a writers' group to critique it and give you comments. Listen to those and incorporate the comments which seem to make sense to you. Repeat for the next scene. Short stories make sense as a start for most writers not because selling short stories is the gateway to becoming a novelist that it used to be, but because if you can't tell a simple story well, you will likely have difficulty telling a longer story with more characters, a more confusing timeline, more plots and subplots, and a greater need for compelling narrative and pacing to keep the reader engaged.

Looking through the answers others have given, I see some conflicting advice. Some say, “Just start writing,” while others say, “Take some instruction, read some how-to books.” You have to know your “big idea” or you have to know how your story ends. You should work your way forward by writing short stories. Or not. The fact is, there are all different ways to write a novel. Some outline the bejeezus out of it before writing the first sentence. Others start with a character and a conflict and see where it goes from there. Some know what their story’s about from the beginning; for others, the meaning of the tale emerges as it develops. For some, it’s all about the “narrative voice.” For others, it’s “show, don’t tell.” Which kind of writer are you? You’ll find out as you try various strategies and approaches and decide which ones fit your way of working. It’s learn-by-doing . What’s the right advice? Whatever works for you. Me, I’m self-taught, although I did read some how-to books at first and found them often contradictory. I sold several novels before I turned to short story writing. It turned out I could do both, although many writers are better at the one than the other. I almost never know how a novel will end, or what it’s about, when I start. (I’ve just completed one that turned out to be a tale of two characters wounded by life who find healing and completion in their unusual relationship; when I started to write it, I thought it would be a broad farce about a burglar haunted by a ghost). So, be prepared to learn as you go. Listen to all the advice you can get, including what’s offered on Quora, then follow the recommendations that feel right to you and ignore the rest. There is no “one right way.” There are many different paths into the forest — and out again — and you have to explore and find the one that’s right for you. My one piece of practical advice: finish your first draft. Don’t keep rewriting the opening chapters, trying to make them perfect. The purpose of the first draft is not to get it right, but to get it written. Once it’s done, you can see the shape of the thing and can start to work on making it better.

Start by taking a hundred sheets of plain paper. Stack them neatly. Now put them aside and start reading lots of novels. Not just those that you admire, but those that you think were terrible. But instead of being drawn in to the story, think of the determination it took to consider each and every word on the page. To write them, cross them out, agonize over the right words, the image you’re creating for the reader. Think of how many different scenes, how many different characters, how vivid they are in your mind. When you’re tired of reading, look at that stack of blank paper again. Consider that the authors of all those novels started with nothing but that, and they kept on writing, and even the writers of the terrible novels though they were writing something good. And remember that you’ll probably need a lot more than one hundred sheets. If you truly believe you can do fill up all those sheets with words that tell a story, and a few more stacks just like it, and keep on going until you finish, then you’re ready to start mapping out the novel you want to write. It’s probably a good idea to have the end in sight at all times, although you can always change the novel’s direction at any time. If you’re not sure, then you’re not ready yet and starting now would probably just give you a membership in the club of wannabe authors who all have a bunch of unfinished novels lying around somewhere. No shame in it, it’s part of the writer’s life. Most successful authors have a bunch of those, too. Once you know you’re ready, and you start mapping it out, you can reach out to other writers for encouragement. There are writers groups on facebook, there may be a writers association or two in your area. Writers are generally interested in helping each other, because while we all know what the world’s oldest profession is, writing is probably one of the loneliest, and only another writer understands.

At some point, you will have an idea and it will occur to you that it might make a fine novel. Your first step is to respect the idea. You do that by not thinking of the idea as just something that passing through your head and letting it bounce around. Take notes and flesh the idea out. Keep the notes with you and add to them whenever you find time. In time, you will decide you have enough notes. You will then want to make an outline. This is when you break your notes down into a distinct order and lay the groundwork for the chapters that will be in your novel. Some lessons in structure will come in handy — especially knowledge of plot, sub-plots, climaxes, and conclusions. You might even play with prologues and epilogues. Go read up. Then comes the first draft. This is a marathon race. You have your outline and now you have to do the actual writing. In my experience, this is the most fun part of writing a novel. It’s not essential, but many writers find a routine — a certain place where they spend a certain part of the day writing a certain number of words every day. The idea is to get the entire story out of you in one go. Don’t worry about quality at this stage as you will come back to the first draft in the near future. After you are done, you may want to put some distance between your draft and yourself. Take a break. Do something else. Travel a little. This helps you see your work from another person’s perspective when you read it again. When you are ready, return to your draft. You will find you don’t feel as strongly for the characters you created. Don’t worry, this is a good thing. You will kill some of them, wipe some of them from existence, and even create new ones to occupy the newly empty spaces. This is all good. This is what second drafts are for. The first draft was you telling the story to yourself. The second draft is you hammering it into a shape that may be better appreciated by others. This is how you start anyhow. Later stages will take you to editors and readers, but all that comes later.

Start writing. Seriously. Okay…there are more books than I care to think about out there that can give you all sorts of methods to write your own novel. So, my advice is my advice-take it as you will. First thing, start from the ending and work backwards. Especially if you’re working on anything that requires you to have a specific ending. You want the two main characters to fall in love at the end of your book and have babies. So, how did we get there? Nobody wakes up one morning, walks outside, finds the first person of compatible sexuality that they can find, walks to the local county clerk/parson/priest/priestess, gets married, does the thing, and has kids. (Okay, maybe, but you better have a really good explanation as to why.) Once you have that done, figure out your waypoints along the way. Two people getting married. Before that, they have to decide why and how they’re getting married. Before that, they have to decide that they like each other enough to get married. Before that, they have to get to know each other. Before that… So, figure out your waypoints. How you want to get from the first words to the end of your story. Then, write. Your goal is three fold. You want to- Work for about an hour a day, and at least five hundred words a dayGet it down nowWorry about everything else laterJust…write. Even if it’s just “this suck” two hundred and fifty times. Even if you’re going off on a tangent you’re going to have to toss. Even if you think “I’m going to have to go back and add more meat to these bones,” don’t worry about that right at that point. WRITE. If you miss a day or two because life has been driving you mad, that’s fine. Just, don’t use it as an excuse to stop writing. Once you get to a point where you’re nearing completion, say about half-way, find people to test-read it. Don’t be around when they do-you want them to read it as “cold” as possible, so they can tell you where there are problems. When you reach the point where it’s done, go through it a few times. Have people try reading it. DON’T get discouraged, but figure out what you did right and wrong. Publishing. There are more books on how to do traditional publishing, independent publishing through Amazon, and the other options. Find those, make notes. Then, once you’ve gotten it published-start on the next novel.

I don’t want to be massively discouraging, but if you even feel the need to ask this kind of question, no you shouldn’t. Lots of people think that they could write a novel. But apart from matters of craft, storytelling, etc., writing a novel requires immense stamina. You’ve really got to get to the end, otherwise you haven’t written a novel, you’ve only started one. If you think you’d quite like to write a novel and are hoping that someone will give you a few tips on how to get started, that’s not how writers think. It’s like asking a musician How can I start writing a song?, except that it’s possible to write a song in a couple of hours; it’s not possible to write a novel in a couple of hours. People who can write songs are able to think of a line, and another line, and then turn that into a verse, and end up with something worth singing. I can’t write songs. Not memorable ones. But I can write fiction, and I’ve finished drafts of more than one novel. (None of which I have yet made any serious attempt to bring to a publisher. But at least I’ve written them.) You should only try writing a novel if you have, in your head, an image of the novel that you want to write—and I don’t mean a vague desire to write that novel, or an idea for a couple of characters, but an actual idea of what the novel is going to be about and how it will start, go on and end. Kind of like the idea that you have in your head of a novel that you’ve already read: you know what it was about, you remember some good bits and good lines, you remember what gripped you and how it worked, more or less, but you can’t recite the whole thing from memory. That’s what it’s like, in my experience, to start out writing a novel. You know what you have to do: it’s a matter of turning that blurry vision into specific words, and you already know some of the things that you’re going to do, in that respect. And you know that it’s a matter of sitting down and working hard until you’ve done it. What it’s not like is: Hmm, maybe I should write a novel. Anyone got any ideas?

Sit down (or stand it doesn’t really matter), think “what do I want to write about?”Write about your answer to oneContinue until book is doneSigh, if only it were that easy. But I have good news! the first step I mentioned above is the real first step. The bad news? That step can be the hardest. Before you can start writing you need to be able to answer these questions: What genre is my book?You don’t want to write a realistic fiction book that turns into a fantasy book halfway through, it’s confusing and will just waste your timeWho is the main character(s)?And if you have multiple main characters: how am I going to divide their screen time? Am I going to write about character A chapter 1, and character B chapter 2?What is the main character(s) goal?Is it a short term or long term goal? How will they accomplish this? What obstacles will they face?What is the main character(s) personality?How am I going to portray this? What are the main aspects of their personality? Think if you’re introducing your character(s) to people at a party what do these people need to know about said character(s).What about background characters?You can’t write a book with just one character (well you probably could, but it might get boring) . Background characters don’t need to be as in-def, but don’t make them zombies, give them some personality.Once you have all these questions answered you have to think about the beginning, middle, and end of the book. Think about scenes your heart is bursting to create; these are your puzzle pieces, arrange them in our mind and try to think of scenes to fill the gaps. After you’ve done all of that you need to plan when to write, and do it. Try to set deadlines if you struggle with this.

“How do I get started on writing my novel? [I have an idea, and a basic plot outline (very basic), but I have no idea how to get started on the actual writing part. Any tips/ tricks?]” Draft. If you check out my answers on writing, you’ll find this advice returning all the time: “Don’t write a novel.” Instead, start writing the draft of a novel. The draft is ‘for your eyes only’, so you can write it any way you want and in any order you want. I favour a typewriter, like this beauty:  The instrument doesn’t really matter, as long as it gets you to bang out the words in more or less coherent sentences. Don’t think too much about structure yet — many writers kill any impetus by spending too much time writing the ‘perfect opening’. Just start writing the scenes you’re enthusiastic about, don’t think about chapters yet, because that is for the later editing stage. You need to write the whole draft first, all of it. You’ll find that when you have the whole story, it’s much easier to find the right opening for your story and you can write it more easily, foreshadowing the events that happen later in the story. If you get stuck, put the scene aside and start writing another scene. You’ll find that a solution for the other scene will present itself when you’re not focused on it, but writing other scenes. When you have a collection of scenes, you can put them in whatever order you like best, then read them through to see if you need to write any transitions between scenes. You’ll find, often, that transitions are not necessary anymore, as they were in the past. Nowadays, with people watching television and movies, the story can jump around without losing the reader, as long as you set the stage at the beginning of each scene. So sit your ass down behind your paper, typewriter, laptop or computer, and start writing a scene. And another. And another.

Okay, buddy, as a fellow mentally-ill writer who can’t get their shit together, I recommend any of the following: Literally just write. It won’t be great, you might never finish it, but it’s a start from which you might actually figure out things about how you function when it comes to writing. Option two is do some planning. Ask yourself what you want to write about. Any novel, even fantasy ones, talks about real world issues. Harry Potter, and I’ll keep using it because everyone has at least heard of it, was not about wizards, but about prejudice, discrimination, courage, trauma, abuse and other stuff like that. Not saying it did it perfectly, but you can see it. When you figure out your message, you can go on to deciding what kind of character best tells your story (I wouldn’t talk about LGBT+ issues using a straight dude as an MC, for example, because of obvious reasons). You also need to know what kind of world best tells your story. My WIP short story is set in a room above the sky with a glass floor. That’s all. Because I’m talking about how god is man made and can only see as much as man can see, hence the isolation and the window no bigger than that floor, and that’s literally all I need. Then you decide the conflict that best tells your story. Apocalypse? War? High school crush? Murder? Always has been printing pentagrams on pads and your period summoned Satan? And then see option one, which is, literally just write. Another thing you can do, not as definitive work but to understand how you deal with the process, is try to improve or work off of stuff you’ve read and liked, or read and didn’t like. Yeah, I’m talking fan fiction. No, you won’t publish it unless it’s public domain now, like Sherlock, but it’s really, really useful, trust me. Creative writing workshops and classes probably won’t hurt you, and they might help, but if you can’t join one, don’t beat yourself up or let that stop you. You don’t need it. I hope you end up finding that happiness. c:

As a joke answer, I recommend you use Microsoft Word on a computer, not paper. Nothing beats a computer for writing books. As a serious answer, whether it’s a blank paper page or a blank computer screen in MS Word, I know it can be intimidating. Here’s my big tip. Don’t try to just start writing your novel immediately. If you want to write one I assume you have some ideas about the genre at least. Maybe you even have a vague notion of a plot. Whatever ideas you have, jot them down as notes and compile these notes in a folder on your computer. If all you have is the genre and perhaps a subject within the genre, that’s okay. Do some reading — research in the area of your subject matter. See what others have written in this area. Google it. Look at sources such as Wikipedia. Go into the Goodreads site and join a group where members read stuff you want to write about and join in the conversations. Keep taking notes. I think you’ll find that eventually a more concrete plot will emerge out of these notes. When you start writing the actual novel, remember the story arc of most good novels. You need to begin with some action, begin with a bang, not a whimper. Set up a conflict that needs to be resolved. You need to have a main character (protagonist) whom readers can identify with. This person is at the center of the conflict. In many good novels there is also the chief villain, or Big Bad Boss. I actually like to model my villains after bad bosses I used to have before I started writing full time. I’m thinking in a future novel I might model my villain after Donald Trump — changing the name to protect the guilty of course. Evolve the conflict to the point of a crisis where it seems the situation might be hopeless. Then think of a way for your hero (protagonist) to succeed against all odds, while not making it unrealistic for him or her to do so. Keep it real. On the other hand if your muse wants you to write a tragedy, you need your character to have a tragic flaw or flaws. S/he still needs to be someone your readers can identify with and cheer for so it will be gut-renching when s/he fails. But it will be understandable because of those tragic flaws. These are personality traits which are the root cause of failure to resolve the conflict with a happy ending. I recommend and other writers do too that you spend half of your writing time reading and taking notes on what you read. Good research will help you overcome writer’s block and fear of the blank page.

Step one: have an idea. This could be ‘I want to write a story about guilt and redemption’ or it could be ‘I want to write a story about people piloting giant mechs against equally giant dinosaurs’. The former is called a ‘theme’. Pretty much everything that happens in the story comes back to guilt and redemption and the novel overall says something about it. Literary fiction loves this approach to writing a novel but a good theme is recommended in any novel. The latter, let’s call it the story’s ‘premise’, is also perfectly fine and is the kind of attitude that leads to franchise fiction, or generic romance novels (though usually with fewer dinosaurs and mechs), or hard-bitten action thrillers. This is the more fun and mass market end of commercial fiction. But, as mentioned above, a good theme is recommended, even if that’s only a justification for the giant fighting robots. (The theme of the film Pacific Rim, for example, could be said to be ‘unity as strength’ or, less poncily, ‘teamwork is good’: the Jaegers require two pilots to work in harmony, the Jaeger project itself is a multi-national endeavour that is being threatened by individual nations cutting funding in order to protect themselves, and even the patriotically-themed star Jaeger crews only succeed when they coordinate their duels with their opposite numbers from other countries, and the protagonist’s arc over the story is learning to work as part of a new team after his brother’s death, while the two scientists learn to stop being rivals and combine their efforts against the kaiju. All of this is a justification for giant robots hitting giant monsters.) I often start with an idea for a cool (to my mind) story, only fleshing out the thematic elements later as the characters and plot develop. My first (unpublished, and probably in need of another polish before I send it to any other agents) novel started out as an investigation into a war crime in a fantasy setting. After the first draft, it became clear that the story was about conscience, the things that people do when they don’t have one, and the sense of duty conscience instills into those that do. (I won’t say it’s an excellent analysis of those themes, but it’s a good excuse for a story featuring demons and psychopaths and politicians, and it does tie things together a bit.) Step two: flesh out the idea. You’ve got your theme and/or premise. You can either just start writing, or you can plan the plot out first. The advantage to the former is that you’ve harnessed the energy and excitement you’re feeling for a new project and are putting words on the page. Words on the page are important if you’re writing a novel; whether they’re good words can be judged later, when it comes to redrafting. The downside is that you don’t necessarily know where you’re going and you may eventually write yourself into a corner, or face-first into a wall. It’s probably better overall to plan the novel before you write it, so that each scene leads onto the next, while you can also lay seeds in earlier scenes that foreshadow later events or character reveals. This can be painstaking, but it gives a good framework to lay your words onto. Think of your plan for the novel as being the poles of a tent, while the words are the canvas. Now picture that tent without the poles to hold it up. You can still sleep inside it, but it’s going to be a rough night. A quick aside: JK Rowling knew how book seven ended even before Harry Potter got his first owl from Hogwarts. Meanwhile, George MacDonald Fraser wrote the first Flashman novel with no plan at all, merely inserting Flashman from Tom Brown’s Schooldays into historical events and seeing how he avoided dying. My personal approach, as a writer without pretensions towards entering the literary canon, is to use that initial burst of enthusiasm to get words onto the page, regardless of where they might lead. I don’t necessarily know how the story’s going to end, or if I do have an idea for the end-point, I don’t know what happens in the middle that takes us from here to there. My current project started with the basic idea ‘a dwarf accidentally destroyed the world by digging too deep’. What followed was a bit of post-apocalyptic grumpiness from a guilt-ridden dwarf with anger management issues. After about 10–15,000 words, or sometimes less, I get a feel for the world I’m trying to write, and the plot of the story becomes clear. At this point, I stop writing and instead start planning the future events of the story, scene by scene, until I reach the end. Who the characters are, why they’re doing what they do, and where they’re going next becomes a lot more clear during this process. Step Three: Keep on writing.

It was 2014. National November Writing Month (NaNoWriMo) had just happened (thousands of people write a 50k word novel during the month of November), and my sister had done it: she’d written a book. Everyone was so proud of her. I am incredibly competitive. I had vowed never to write. Perfection had owned me at seven, when I tried to write a story and couldn’t get past the second chapter–I thought it wasn’t good enough, so I wrote it again and again and again. I never finished it. But I thought, if she could do it, why couldn’t I? I had an idea. And it wouldn’t let me go. So, on the night of December 23rd, 2014, I sat down and wrote that idea out. About three hours later, it was early morning, and I checked my word count. I had written ten thousand words. I was going to write a novel.  Since that night four years ago, I’ve written nearly 500,000 words toward this novel. I’ve loved it. It’s a giant project that forces me to think, to explore ideas, to empathize with stories that will never be mine in order to write realistically. A lot of people might tell you to plot, a lot of people might tell you to “pants” it. I do both. I started with an idea. It burned on my mind until I got it onto the page, and then it grew, so I knew I had to write more about it. Over the four years of working on this thing, I’ve realized a few things I wish I would’ve done at the beginning: You need a character you’re willing to spend a lot of time with. It took about eight months for me to name my character, and I stole his voice from another character whom I loved, who talked in such a specific way I knew I had to use it (I just couldn’t let that character be the protagonist. He’s pretty mad at me now). But you need a character. This character can be anyone.Choose their goal. What do they want most? That’s their goal. It’s something they want above all else, something they’ll do anything to achieve. Their goal is even better if it’s story-centric (sometimes if you dream up a bit of the story before choosing a goal, you’ll get a more story-centric goal for your character). The goal is the most important thing about a story. It becomes the point of the story itself.You need a plot. But don’t overthink it–the plot is simply, How does this character think they’ll get to their goal? This is the plot. This is their plan.Add stakes. Every excellent story has stakes. Stakes are the “before something happens to stop the character from reaching their goal” part. They should have a timeline (the “before something happens”). What will stop them from reaching their goal? Not just could, but what will stop them? Answering this question will help you create high stakes–the best kind of stakes.Make the story. How do they actually get to their goal? This is the story. This is what you read.However, in all honesty, to write a novel, you really only need to do one important thing: write.

There are already 50 answers here, some of which I read, but just thought I’d toss my two cents in as well. When I first started writing, I posted my stories in an email group, (this was back in the 90s) and I was fortunate in that another writer liked my ideas enough to offer to beta read my next story. See, my grammar was atrocious. I was in my 30s and it had been years since 7th grade English class and all of the grammar homework. My career is in healthcare and so the only writing I ever did was in patient charts and fiction is frowned upon. ;) The beta reader patiently pointed out my errors, showed me how to correct them, and even more importantly, showed what my strengths were as well. That gave me the confidence to continue writing. I sought out books on writing, found websites, and continued to practice. As others have suggested, short stories are a good vehicle to get your writing polished and find your voice. Some people over-write, where they add a ton of extra details, but my biggest problem was writing too sparsely. I had to learn to flesh out the stories. Check your local We are what we do | MeetupRe-write.Apply what you learn.Repeat the above.

“Once upon time…” But seriously, you need to find your own technique. There are plenty of cheap books that you can buy that tell you this, how to plan chapters, flesh out characters, all that sort of thing. You can even get ideas for topics. My first novel I wrote the chapter that was most vivid and structured as a short story, then it evolved backwards to lead up the that chapter and forwards as the story progressed, it ended up as chapter 6! I suppose I did plan it out, but in my head, I used to take the scenic route to work, turn the radio off and just run through in my head, gradually honing and tweaking until I had something to start writing. I don’t agree with starting with the end or the beginning, just start - the hardest thing is starting, once you have started writing you can then start worrying about what and where. I find it useful to have a list of points of reference, mine was the date the two leads met, I then calculated birthdays and other significant events from that.(This is all for my personal reference, not to go in the book, just helps me keep it realistic and consistent, so for instance a character doesn’t have two birthdays in one year!). I also make notes of chapter headings to help plan how the story evolves and If I have ideas for later I write them now, even though it may be three or four chapters on before I get to them, just don’t want to lose the idea. So you get a rough plan of where your story starts, who is in it, how it ends, and a rough idea of the journey between. It all depends what works for you, some I believe write the ending first and work back. The best thing in my experience is to write what is on your mind now, the fist page is the hardest, once you have started it will just go as it will, it is just that “breaking the ice” as it were and starting. Word processors are great though, I do most on that, I only really use a pen for editing. When I was at school, and I hated writing by hand, I can’t even read my handwriting, and then I would end up with most of the page crossed out and endless re-writes. With a word processor you can cut and paste, park and save bits to one side if you love the passage but it doesn’t fit the story just yet, or at all but may make a good different story. I am a sort of hybrid though, I need to see it printed out to properly edit so I tend to write a chapter, print it and proof read and edit and mark-up changes.

If writing a novel is your dream, then you need to get started right away my friend because it is a big and challenging task, with many problems that await you. But if you are really up for it, then I am happy to extended my help ( being in the process of writing one myself.) CASE 1: NEW TO WRITING. If you are quite new to writing and haven’t written a lot of stuff before then the path is as follows. Start writing short stories and poems. And do this for about an hour everyday. Ruskin Bond Once said in an interview “ Writing requires army discipline”. And boy yes it does. Write a page every day. No matter how crappy it seems but keep writing. This is the first step to writing your novel. Once you have the discipline down, start writing longer and more structured stories and poems, and get them reviewed from DIFFERENT people. If they criticize, don't let it get to you, take it positively and Just keep writing. This will give you an idea of how you write. And mind it, these people should not necessarily be your family (as all they usually have is praise, even for shitty stuff :P) Now if you successfully get this done, then you really are interested in writing and you become a Case 2 writer. (as follows) CASE 2: HAVE BEEN WRITING FOR A WHILE. If this is the case then, follow these steps:- Get the central idea ready. You need to have a clear picture of what your story is, who it is about, in which world it is based, what happens at various points in the time line. WRITE THIS ALL DOWN. Changes in the story will happen but don't worry about it at this point of time. Just let the ideas flow naturally and organically.2. This step is about actually writing. There are many methods you can Follow, like the snowball method, it is basically what works for you. Google a list of different methods or just follow your own strategy. The only thing to be kept in mind is regularity and ORGANIC flow of ideas. These two steps are the essence of writing any novel and the rest of the journey becomes clearer as we progress. PS: Organic flow of ideas means that you don't need to force any instance in your story. If your initial story and your “story world” is clear then instances will automatically start making sense on paper and your ideas will flow more naturally. Just be clear about what you are writing. Also, don't block and bias your thoughts to suit your story, you never know the gem of an idea you reject. Just harness the natural flow.

Choose your genre Every genre has separate set of readers. So, first choose your genre. Research on your target audience Before you pick a paper and pen, first know your target audience. Know how your target audience has reacted to the recent novels in your genre. Study your target audience. Know exactly what they are looking for nowadays. Convince a unique story Your story must be unique in all aspects. Every story you read is similar, yet different. That ‘difference’ is the uniqueness of the story. If your story is not unique, then it will be just like a raindrop in an ocean. Even though there will be millions of books in the genre you write, your book has to stand alone. Example: The Hobbit, A Song of Ice and Fire (Game of Thrones), and Harry Potter Series. These three belong to the same genre – fantasy, but the content of the story is unique. That is why these books are considered great by critics and audience. Prepare story outline It is absolutely necessary to prepare the story outline. You must know the flow of your story, where it is starting, how it proceeds, how it concludes. A well-drafted outline clearly reflects the essence of a story. Create compelling characters Characters are the blood and spine for every story. Your characters must be interesting, unique, and attractive. Always concentrate on each character’s story arc. They must be realistic and connect easily to the readers. Don’t add some characters because you like them, your readers must like them, your readers must fall in love in them, your readers must be inspired and idolize them. A strong character has a strong background. Don’t create single line characters. Example: Even if a character is pure evil, there must be different shades of evil. Don’t just show that character as only evil. A realistic character is not always evil. Your characters must sound realistic, move realistic, and talk realistic. When the story proceeds, the character must also move forward. A character must not be same in the end, as it was in the beginning. Structure your story with checkpoints Checkpoints are mandatory. While writing your novel always keep check points in the story, so that you can navigate easily. Even keep checkpoints in the chapters, so you will not get deviated. Keeping checkpoints will help you to measure the length of your novel, and how long or how short you are about to finish your work. Set a goal – Daily, weekly, monthly. Writing without a goal is like running with eyes closed. Set a goal clearly. Set a realistic one. No one can finish an entire novel in a week. Setting realistic goals and achieving them will boost your confidence. Finish the first draft Your first priority while writing a novel is to finish the first draft. First draft is the rough idea of what you have in your mind about your novel. Don’t refine the first draft without finishing it completely. If your novel has 18 chapters, finish all those chapters in the first draft and then start to refine it. Don’t look back or modify the content while writing a first draft. If you do, you must understand you got yourselves in a quicksand. You will be stagnated in the same place, it will become difficult to move forward. Revise! Revise! Revise! A first draft is not the final material. After finishing the first draft, refine it, write a second draft. Write many and many drafts until you are satisfied with your story. Revise! Revise until your eyes ache. Revise until you are confident enough to say ‘I don’t need to change a single letter.’

First of all, do a lot of reading of good novels. Nobody teaches us how to write. You can go to a workshop, take a seminar, get a few pointers, but no one really teaches us how to construct a novel, make exciting characters, etc. You can only learn through reading how other writers have done it successfully and by starting to copy them then letting your imagination flow into your own ideas, thoughts, and emotions. My favorite writers are Mikhail Bulgakov, Salman Rushdie, Gabriel Garcia-Marquez, Annie Dillard, Victor Hugo, and Shakespeare. Shakespeare was not a novelist, but I think he is the go-to man for learning the full potential of the English language. This is how I approached my first novel (which I threw out because I didn’t like it and the premise was eventually unworkable) as well as the one I am working on currently. 1. I get ideas for some characters, then I make notes on them, think about them a lot, do some psychological research and research on the location they are in, maybe some history, and make lots of notes. 2. Then I imagine the characters in situations with the other characters and what kinds of stories might come out of that; then my plot comes out of that. I get a lot of ideas away from my desk or computer. I carry a notebook and a pen wherever I go, because it seems a lot of ideas come to me whilst I am on a walk. 3) I copy all my ideas into my computer and rearrange them to make a plot which is chronological and which has every event being caused by the prior events. 4) When all the events and thoughts are in chronological order, that is my outline. I then work on each event in the outline, fleshing them out with description, dialogue and action. I do a lot of rewriting on the spot before I move to the next section, making sure that I am making each section ripe with tension and meaning. After I have finished the entire book, I reread and rewrite many times, thinking about what themes I have written unconsciously and how I might be able to add a line or symbol here and there to bring that theme out. I do a lot of wild writing that Natalie Goldberg talks about in her books. There is so much information and so many ideas that are in our subconscious that are waiting to come out if we only pay attention to them. Especially if I am stuck on a scene, I do a lot of wild writing on it to get to the heart of the matter. The Art Of Fiction by John Gardner has been very helpful to me. It is the best book on writing stories and novels that I have ever come across. Don’t write to sell, don’t write to become famous or rich. Find ideas and emotions that grab you in your gut, which put a taste in your mouth, and write about those. Write only with the mind to bring to light the full potential of your thoughts and ideas. That is how you will become a good writer. If your book is meant to sell, then it will. All the best! Open a Word document right now. Type down every idea you have and include every detail that comes to mind. Give the file some appropriate name (like Novel Draft), and add to it continuously. Think about the story and what you’ve already written as much as you can throughout the day and night, and constantly update and revise what you have. Novels have a lot of dialogue, so constantly be on the hunt for witty, clever, or entertaining things to say—even if they aren’t directly related to the plot or the themes of the novel. As a first-time fiction author, you want to shoot for anywhere between 70k-90k words (to increase your chances of getting a deal), so you will likely find some way to work most of these ideas in eventually. I cannot stress the importance of actually typing these things out, because doing so will help the ideas take better shape in your mind. Also, humans are very forgetful creatures, so don’t expect to remember the brilliant idea you had yesterday if you didn’t write it down. When the file has gotten sufficiently full with content, start organizing the ideas into sections, and start to build an outline from that. As the file gets bigger, you will need to create new documents to best keep track of everything (Novel Ch. 1 draft, Novel outline, Novel Dialogue Ideas, Novel Characters, etc.) Little by little, you’ll start to see the vision of the book more clearly. And guess what? You’ll already have tons of ideas and lines of dialogue to work with. It is exactly like doing a puzzle: at first there are tons of pieces and they all have cool shapes and colors but you have no idea where any of them go. But as you begin to place things where they belong it becomes easier and easier, and the image you are trying to create comes better into focus. Oh, and one more thing. Be obsessive. This is your chance to make your masterpiece. Give it all you have. And know that it won’t be easy or happen overnight. Great works of art take time. But when it’s all done, you’ll feel a deep sense of pride and accomplishment, and you’ll deserve it.

Thanks for the A 2 A, A novel is a piece of art. It is a story that embodies its own truth, just like a masterpiece painting or sculpture. The difference is that your medium is words rather than paint or stone. Just like the painter, your style and approach needs to be yours alone. Sure, anybody can buy a paint by number set and create a painting, but that is not art, it is merely an exercise in the skill of painting.Some painters will sketch in pencil, or use a photograph as a starting point. You can do the same thing to create a novel. Many professional writers will draft a plot line, story arcs, outlines, character sketches, backstories etc. tons of work before they get to the storytelling, which is really just filling in the details and connecting the dots.I have been a storyteller for a long time. One of my favorite past times is to sit in a public place, say a food court at the mall, a public park, a library or maybe a train station and watch people. Then I will pick someone, maybe they seem sad, or distracted or are just really attractive, whatever. I then start creating a story around them. Why are they there, at that time, dressed that way. Where are they going, what is happening in their life? I create my own back story for them. It's like starting from a photograph.Tell the story behind a real life event. Imagine how and why it came to be.Sometimes I will start from a story someone tells me. I could just narrate it as creative nonfiction, or I can use it as a jump off for something completely fresh. My last novel was created in that manner. A woman told me her story. It was absolutely horrific, involving years of violent sexual and domestic abuse. I could have written her story as an essay or journalistic piece, but instead I decided to use it as the underpinning of a novel about courage and redemption.At some point, the painter has to put brush to canvas and start painting; same thing goes for writing. If you are going to write a novel, you have to write that first word, then the second, and so on. I know that before I wrote my first novel, I had no idea if it was something I could do. Did I have the stamina to write something over 60,000 words? I remembered struggling to write a ten page short story back in school. I just had to try. And you know what? I discovered that I really love writing! I love the whole process, the thinking, the research, the writing and the revision process, all of it. I'm not so crazy about the getting it published aspect, but I accept that as part of the process. Maybe I'll get a new agent who makes it easier.But I must say, that even if I never published another book, I would still write, just because I love writing.Tell a story. It might start off as a short story, maybe even stay as that. Or it might grow into something more. Many award winning novels start as one thing and kind of morph into something else. Tell the story that makes you feel something. If you tell a story that makes you laugh, chances are others will laugh too. If you tell a story that makes you weep, others will be moved as well. Draw your reader into your story so that they see it and feel it. That is the difference between reporting and novel writing.One more thing, be more careful with your writing. I mean this as a kindness rather than a criticism. In your question, you made two grammar errors and a spelling mistake. If you are going to be a writer, that kind of laziness will not serve you.Good luck. Work hard and create art every day.

To quote Mary Poppins: “Well begun is half done.” It sounds like you are overthinking it. The process of writing a novel is indeed daunting, but if the story you have in mind is fully formed or compelling enough, it will not be as difficult to follow through once you’ve begun. While many people start novels they never finish, the fact that you are going through the trouble to ask this question on Quora suggests to me that you are taking a methodical and well-planned approach to your novel and are not, as some say, “pantsing it.” If you are truly this personality type, the hardest part will be beginning. Once something is on the page, your main struggle will be to not get caught up in editing as you go. While that works for some writers, a meticulous personality will be more likely to finish the project if he/she punches out a rough draft without looking back, which they then can treat as the rough rock from whence their novel is carved. The carving process is actually very enjoyable for those of us who are perfectionists, so you can look forward to that part:) To sum up, my advice is start already! Write a scene from the middle first if you can't decide where in the story timeline your novel should begin. Or you can even write a backstory scene that won't appear in the book as a way to familiarize yourself with your characters and further develop your voice. Don't worry too much about the rough draft, though. They're supposed to be rough! Just write SOMETHING. That will get you rolling. Good luck!

I love all the advice you've been given and, it's really good advice to take. I just thought I would add a little to it. Since you have an outline of sorts, in assuming you know all your characters? Do you have an idea / plot? Your dreams of writing a novel will go much smoother if you do. Do you have a beginning, middle, and end? All three parts are crucial. Do you have an outline of the story so you know where the "beats" / plot points fall during the course of the novel? This might help. Some people write "by the seat of their pants," make it up as they go along, and then go back to polish the story later. Some outline all the major (and sometimes even the minor) details. Some, like me, do a combination of both. Do you have characters to overcome and provide the conflict in your plot? Again, these are crucial to you having any hope of writing a novel? Do have a lot of time? Writing a novel takes a considerable amount of time. Weeks at minimum, but possibly years. Do you have an understanding spouse / family / boss / group of friends? Be prepared to not have much time to socialize or do your best work at your non-writing job if you're committed to writing a novel? Do you have a good amount of savings and a well-kept home? Be prepared to live off your savings if you don't have another job. Also, home repairs and chores will often fall by the wayside while writing your novel, so I hope you don't need to repair a roof, install a sink, or even mow the lawn anytime soon. Do you enjoy spending nice days outside, going to parties, seeing movies, or binge watching TV? Get ready to stop doing all three because you're going to be too busy writing your novel. It's that easy!
