Most writers know enough to put in sensations beyond sight and sound. It’s always great to read about a character who takes note of the hot metal-and-oil aroma that lingers over the rails after a fast train has passed, or the weight of a new tweed coat on his shoulders. Agents and editors love the five senses, but they want and expect more. They want physical business that deepens not just your setting, but your characterizations. Here’s the key: The best authors use body language in their narratives. Odd thing is, I have never once heard an agent or editor comment on my (or any author’s) use of body language, and I think that’s because it goes by so smoothly it’s almost unnoticed. Yet it absolutely gives texture and depth to your work. When it’s missing, fiction feels flat. Begin by reading up on body language. You’ll find that two things are at the root of all of it: anxiety (or lack thereof) and hidden desires. Dwell inside your characters and sense how they feel in any given situation. Take an hour and write a one-sentence summary of your novel. Something like this: “A rogue physicist travels back in time to kill the apostle Paul.” (This is the summary for my first novel, Transgression.) The sentence will serve you forever as a ten-second selling tool. This is the big picture, the analog of that big starting triangle in the snowflake picture.When you later write your book proposal, this sentence should appear very early in the proposal. It’s the hook that will sell your book to your editor, to your committee, to the sales force, to bookstore owners, and ultimately to readers. So make the best one you can!

Everyone has a different approach to writing a novel. Judy Gill’s approach is very different to mine. I need to know where I’m going. So I first sketch out the story idea. Then I expand on the growing plot, explaining who the characters are, their relationship to each other and their motivation. Then I expand on that, adding more detail. Pretty soon, I’ve got a scenario taking place that I can divide into three acts. I begin to get a feeling for the flow of the story, its peaks and troughs, pacing and intrigue. At that point, if I’ve really got a feel for the whole story, I might write the opening chapter. But it won’t be a honed chapter. It will be a taste of it, the hint of blue touch paper, what’s really at its heart. After that, I would recommend getting into the opening three chapters. They won’t be perfect, but you will have opened up a path for yourself. From then on in, I can’t advise you, because it totally depends on the nature of your story. All I can say is, don’t rush it. And be prepared to re-craft the entire novel when you get to the end. Because by then, you’ll understand far more than you did in the beginning. Many novelists write seven or eight drafts. You won’t need to change the basic plot; you just make it better and better, with moments of inspiration, until it’s as good as you can get it. Go at it. You’re probably going to starve before it’s published, but hey, nothing’s easy.

I was catching up on some of the fiction bestsellers by Indian authors a few years back. I then realized that I had a story to tell which was much more interesting and entertaining than a lot of novels that were out there. When I decided that I wanted to write a novel, I had a basic idea about the story I wanted to tell. I was traveling on work and away from family for about a month. I formed a routine for that month and after coming back from work, I just sat at a desk in my hotel and typed out the story which I wanted to tell. About 60% of the novel was complete before I came back home. Establishing a routine to write is very important to complete what you started. It is also very important - especially for first timers - that you find a story you really want to tell. That was the only thing which enabled me to start and even complete my novel when all the glamour associated with writing had gone away and I was staring at this white sheet which I had to fill. If you write a story you don’t feel strongly enough about, why would people even want to read your story. If you don't have a story worth telling, then you might as well stop wasting your time right now. If you have a story worth telling and you combine it with love for writing, you will succeed The story I wanted to tell needed to be told differently - first person accounts of events and emails. The format emerged from the story I had to tell. I tried different narration styles, but they weren’t telling the story the way it needed to be told. It had to be how it ended up being –emails and first person accounts of events by different characters in every alternate chapter. When I was struggling to get the narration style and structure right, I joined a three week in residence ‘Just Write’ fiction writing workshop back in 2011 in Bangalore, where I got a chance to learn the nuances of and hone my story telling skills from authors Anil Menon, Anjum Hasan and Rimi Chatterjee. I did not worry too much about editing at every opportunity - it would have prevented me from telling my story. I finished up on the story I wanted to tell and then worried about editing. I did not worry either about having that immaculate grammar or language skills when writing. They developed as I wrote. I read and re-read books and novels which I loved which went a long way in helping me improving my writing and language skills. I asked myself these questions when I was writing my novel: What is the the special story I want to tell?Am I happy with what I have written?Is this how I want to tell the story?What is different about the story I want to tell?And why should people read my story?Writing a book has been an experience which I would cherish for the rest of my life and I am glad I went through the process. I will leave you with a quote from Maya Angelou which I feel is apt here - ‘There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you.’

Spend as much time as you can improving your writing skills. To do this, you have to read and write a lot. You should be spending time everyday reading and writing. Be sure to vary up what you read; don’t just read in the genre you are interested in writing. Try to absorb good writing from everywhere you can. Take note of what makes for good writing and for a good story. Study writing and always strive to learn and improve. Write everyday. It doesn’t matter what it is necessarily. It can be a short story, novel, poem, journal entry, or even a Quora answer. Just be sure to write everyday. If you don’t know what to write about, write about not knowing what to write. Having someone read and critique your work may help you, so consider reaching out to other writers. Look for people more and less experienced than you. Look for someone you can teach, and for someone that can teach you. These connections will allow you to learn more. You could also just have a friend or family member read your work. Remember you want them to critique your work. Remind them that you don’t want generic compliments - you want real advice that will help you improve. This means you can’t take their criticism personally. Rather, you must appreciate and evaluate it. And know that it’s okay to reject their advice. You have to determine for yourself what you need to change to improve the piece. But regardless of how useful their criticism was, be sure to thank them for their time. Other things that may help, yet are not necessary, include pursuing a creative writing or English degree and attending writer workshops. Yet if you want to hone your craft, there are two things that are necessary: reading and writing. And you will have to put the time into it everyday. Do this, and you will certainly improve. Remember to stay patient; writing can be a fun and adventurous, yet it can also be exhausting. There may be days where you find it extremely difficult to write. You may become frustrated and disappointed. You may begin to doubt your ability to write, and you may grow to hate everything you’ve written. You may simply not feel like writing. Push through those feelings, and keep writing - it’s the only way to improve. Remember that you write because you love it and that being good isn’t a requirement. And go back into the piece with a clear mind, and an objective: improving it. And if you want to be happy: take care of yourself by getting enough sleep, eating healthily, exercising, being around people you love, taking time to relax, and by doing what you love.

All the lessons that you have learnt and all the things that you feel should be known by other people. Write about everything that you think isn't proper and needs to be in some other way. When you will write something which isn't right, your mind will try to struggle with the replacement of something better with it. And for that, you will automatically start researching. Not just in case of engineering college, I am talking about any other issue. Religion and mythology. Political sciences. Policies, laws and bills. Government and economics. Everywhere this same principle applies. So write. Write all you feel, and all you think should be known by other people. And Look, you never know what will turn into a novel. And what will turn into a mere garbage. And even if you create a novel, you never know what will publishers like. Many a times publishers reject a manuscript even when it is beautifully written or extensively researched. They reject because they fail to find such pieces making well in the market. To them, writing is a pure business. But you create such a masterpiece that could flourish even without shooting by a mainstream media. A traditional publisher. Give your best. For example: Amish Tripathi was rejected by almost every traditional publisher of our country. Because they didn't feel that mythology will survive in the market. But then, Amish believed in his work, and he finally self-published it. Today, the same book has sold over 2 million copies! So you just write. Don't think whether it will turn into a novel. Or whether your dream publisher will accept it or reject it. Just start writing. And by the time you will finish one page, you will get a story of another 5 pages. By the time you will finish writing 5 pages, your mind will produce ideas for the next 10 pages. And this cycle continues till a beautiful novel is born. I hope that will be enough for kick-starting your work. All the best!

Ernest Hemingway was once asked by a college student, “Do you make an outline of your novels before you start writing?” Hemingway said “No, I just start.” I have a draft of a novel on my desk. I had an idea in my head of what this book would be about, who the characters would be…..all based on events I’d experienced and people I knew. An idea came to me of a conversation that very well could have happened. Using the inflections and attitude of real guys I knew, knowing what they’d say and do in such a dialogue, I just started with “I’m not driving for you guys.” “I don’t give a rat’s ass what you do,” Dan said, looking at me sideways. Don’t be afraid to begin by jumping right into the midst of talk or action, or even stream of consciousness, interior monologue. This is something that Hemingway bared to the world for the first incredible time in literature. Thoughts that flow constantly through EVERYONE’S mind. For a great example of interior monologue, read Salinger’s “The Catcher in the Rye.” Fantastic! A mind’s conversation with itself should be natural and easy; never stilted! By the way, small writing tips. Never begin a sentence with “The.” Instead of….”The cat jumped off the table and ran out the door—” Write…… “Leaping off the table, the cat fled out the door—-” Avoid like death the word “That.” Write realistic dialogue, not contrived. Listen to the way people talk. I’ve done it since childhood. Even today, in the grocery store, I listen to random people yakking with each other. It fascinates me. Don’t use profanity gratuitously. Use it as a part of real language and/or dialogue. Metaphor and imagery, when used correctly, can be powerful! A turning-word or phrase will be “Like a…” or “As.”…….. “He came through the door like an angry gorilla!” Ending and starting paragraphs is WAY more important than you realize. As soon as your prose shifts gears, hit return/enter and begin a new paragraph. On Quora I see people’s answers with long blocks of uninterrupted narrative. Paragraphs give the reader a split-second chance to rest their brain. Hemingway wrote with great economy. Don’t waste a word or a sentence. And don’t use big words just to show off your vocabulary. You may know a million words and their meanings, and love them. But don’t clog up your prose with multi-syllable favorites…… my hero Hemingway was once criticized for not using descriptive adjectives like his contemporary, William Faulkner. Hemingway responded simply: “I know the words.” ALWAYS see your writing from the perspective of a total stranger with your book in their hands! Never be afraid to start a novel! If you’ve got a story worth telling and you think it might sell, go for it. Avoid like the plague writer’s block. Beginning a novel is rough….but once you start, your creativity will flow out on the screen/paper. Kinda like stepping into a lake, thinking the water will be cold. Then you wade out there and hey, it’s not so bad. Not sure if it’s still around, but check out Writer’s Market, geared towards How To Present and Sell. Find out how book publishers accept new writer’s work, in what format, and the first steps in approaching a publisher. Never get it in your head that what you’ve dashed off is golden and untouchable. Put it down, come back in a few hours and you’ll see mistakes and begin editing. Fine-tune your writing with 2 or 3 drafts, without over-working it in such a way that your original spark becomes muffled. Remember, book publishers have editors who will go to work on YOUR work.

response.answer_text: Just start writing. Perhaps get a journal or a largish notepad and start writing down ideas in pen or pencil. Once you find an idea you like, decide what type of story it is. A true (nonfiction) type, or a made up ((fiction) one. From there pick a sub category (or genre as they are also called) and from there write in the genre of your choosing about your idea. And decide here your point of view. You know, first person, third person omniscient, and so on. Those things that your English or writing instructors will typically teach you about. English grammar books would be helpful for you in order to learn more about that and any necessary mechanical things you might need to learn like sentence structure, comma usage, run on sentences, and so on. And about grammar usage. As you write remember to write like you are showing your readers what is going on rather than telling them. Especially if you are writing fiction. And do not get overly descriptive. This should help you get started a little bit. I hope this is helpful to you. Oh and you can write your novel in pen in a journal if you just want it for yourself. But if you want to write it for the public, consider using a laptop, tablet, or computer, and a word processing program like Microsoft Word.

The first step is to read novels. Lots of them, from the 18th century through the present. There is no better way to understand what a novel is, and what different strategies in creating a novel are. Once you have done that, there are two ways of writing a novel—either plan it out, beginning, middle, and end, and write to the outline, or start with a situation and characters and let them evolve. (Either way, I’d second the suggestion to figure out what the end should be.) I think that writing to a plan is probably a better discipline, particularly for a first novel. I would add that, unless you are writing for your own satisfaction and don’t care about an audience, you ought to bear a few things in mind: Have a definite plot and don’t get sidetracked.Shoot the sheriff on the first page—not literally, but make sure that you have something in your first few pages to involve the reader’s interest.Don’t neglect the details of the setting—don’t try to write a novel about life in a law firm unless you know how a law firm works.Characters are more than a physical description and a few attitudes. Remember to look at them at people. One trick is to write a short bio of each of your characters. Make them psychologically plausible.Enjoy it.

Begin with character. Make her flawed and believable. Let her live and breathe and give her the freedom to surprise you and take the story in unexpected directions. If she’s not surprising you, you can bet she’ll seem flat to your readers. One exercise I always do when I’m getting to know a character is ask her to tell me her secrets. Sit down with a pen and paper and start with, “I never told anybody…” and go from there, writing in the voice of your character.Give that character a compelling problem. Your character has to have something that’s going to challenge her, torment her and propel her forward. At the heart of every story is conflict – whether external or internal, make it a good one, and remember that this problem is going to shape your character, leaving her forever changed.Make things happen! You can have the greatest characters in the world, and write beautifully, but if nothing’s happening, the story falls on its face pretty quickly. In my books, I make sure something important to the plot is happening in each scene. And if there’s a scene in there that isn’t helping to move the story along in some vital way, I cut it, no matter how great it is. When I’m editing, I’ll go scene by scene and write a single word sentence describing the action on an index card. Then I lay the cards out and I’ve got the bare bones of my story. I can see if things are moving forward, if I’m throwing in enough twists and turns, and if there are scenes that just aren’t pulling their weight.

Pick a subject. Write out the major and most salient points. Once you have that done, then take each major heading and begin listing the specific ideas that would comprise each segment. Use this procedure all the way from start to finish. Now, you'll (hopefully) have a reasonably concise detailed outline upon which to build your novel, the beginning or introduction, general overview, and the ending. The next step is to think about what you would like to write and where it might fit within your outline. Don't worry about grammar or punctuation that much at this point; get your thoughts down on paper. Write as much as you possibly can at one sitting, without interruptions. Go where the spirit moves you. Remember, you can always edit it out. I've used this general method for years, whether a short article or something a lot more involved. Yes, it's tough to get started, but once you get your get your ideas down, it really does become easier, more like a “fill-in-the-blanks” series of opportunities to express yourself and tell a story. After all, that's what you will be doing: Crafting a well organized story complete with exciting characters, twists and turns, maybe some sex, and then a wonderful ending. Good luck.

"Read over your compositions,and where ever you meet with a passage you think is particularly fine,strike it out."-Samuel Johnson You have a desire to write,desire will take you a long way provided you supplement it with a few routine habits.The art of writing like with many others comes with effort,practice and flair(don't let negativity get the better of you with the last one). Come up with an idea. Before you begin writing your book, you will need to have an idea. This is the seed from where your book growsResearch your concept. Once you have a vague concept, start researching to get more ideas. For example, you want to write a book about kids playing a futuristic video game. Do some research by going to arcades, reading up on the latest game innovations, and playing some games yourself. In doing these activities, you may see or experience things which give you ideas for what the story can be about or could be included in a story. Develop your concept. With a few ideas about what could be included in a story, you will want to develop your concept. Make the concept more complex by following it to its logical conclusion, thinking about what might result from the set of circumstances, or anything else to make it a more complex idea. Having a more developed concept will help you build your plot. Consider your audience. When coming up with and developing your concept, you will need to consider your audience. Whom are you writing this book for? Different people are into different things and there be particular sets of experiences and prior knowledge to go with the various demographics. You will need to consider this so you understand how to proceed with the plot, characters, and how the book is written.

There are two ways to write a novel:  1. You already know the story.  - Outline the story into chapters - Write your first draft as if it is the most epic creation. Don't think or worry about what you are writing. Just write. - A schedule helps to ensure that you complete it. - Once you finish writing it, keep it aside for a week or two. Then come back to it and review/rewrite/edit. Quick tips: Ensure you have a story arc. Google if you don't know what a story arc is. | Adverbs and adjectives are usually flab. Slash them whereever unnecessary. | Do a minimum of five to eight edits. Word count worries should come by your fourth edit.  2. You don't know the story but have a starting point or an inspiration.  - Start writing. - Identify what works for you: writing for longer stretches or writing a minimum word count everyday. Write. - Same tips on first draft, rewrite and edit as above.  A few things you will need to research and practice: Character mapping, Writing outlines, Setting (Place, era, etc), Plot Some novels don't have plots, but they are well written. All resources are available online for free.  You will also need three people who can give you honest feedback, preferably individuals who read a lot or other writers. If you don't have anyone, then there are some companies who provide literary reviews for a certain cost. Alternatively, you may find freelancers for a lower cost.  Good luck

You need to know what is going to happen before you write the book rather than decide what will happen while it is in progress. That will help you avoid a first pitfall (what do I write next?) and leads us to the next item. 1. Synopsis. You need an out line of your story, a few brief paragraphs with small detail on beginning middle and end. 2. Use a working list of chapters, detailing how you would like each one to go and for the novel to progress. You may also have a forward and afterword or other things to add. 3. Make a list of important details that can cause your novel to be inconsistent if forgotten, thereby making you look clumsy. You do not want to say that Sally drives a blue Chevy in chapter 1 and (having forgotten about that detail) have her drive a red Toyota in chapter 7. Make a list of character names and birthdays, what they drive, who they married, where they live, what they do and don't like, etc... so you remain consistent. In fact... 4. It is a good idea to write a brief biography of each of your characters before you even start writing. Know them and know your story before you even begin. There is more, but some of these preparations are a matter of personal taste and experience as well. The point is, if you take the time to make these preparations beforehand, things will go much more smoothly. I have learned this the hard way.

It depends on what you mean by a “new” writer. Does the extent of your writing consist of essays and other papers you wrote for high school and college? Have you written any blog posts, answers to Quora questions, or perhaps some news articles for your college or local newspaper? Or are you a veteran writer who just hasn’t written a novel? I ask because if you have no writing experience beyond what you may have done in high school or college, it’s best if to get some before starting a huge venture like a novel, or you might be setting yourself up for failure. Find some places to write, perhaps on Quora or another web site that suits your interest, and spend time getting a sense of what it’s like to write every day. Spend a good half hour to an hour a day or more, if possible. Have someone who’s familiar with good writing read your work and make suggestions on how you can improve. See if you actually like writing, because it’s not easy, and not everyone enjoys the process. Once you’ve gotten comfortable as a casual writer, there’s nothing wrong with trying your hand at a novel, perhaps a short one of 50,000 words or so. That’s how long my first novel was, and it currently sits in the proverbial bottom of my desk drawer, never to be seen or read by anyone again. That’s probably where your first novel will also end up, unless you’re really lucky or talented, but it’s still worth trying. My tips for getting started are below: Make sure you’ve read lots of novels, but not just any novels. Read novels in the genre you want to write about. In my case, it was alternative history, so I read some alternative history novels to get a sense of how they’re done.Before starting to write, research your topic. Mine was 9/11 and the hijackers, so I read lots of non-fiction books about the attacks and the people behind them and became something of an expert. This wasn’t hard for me, because the topic was so interesting (which is why I wanted to write a novel about it in the first place). If you don’t feel like reading some non-fiction concerning the time and and place your novel is going to cover, you’re probably not all that interested in writing about that particular subject. Consider something different.Some people like to write Victorian novels, or novels about Roman times. Others want to have their stories take place in some foreign, exotic location (or even on another planet). That’s fine, but remember that people reading the book will probably have some expertise about those times or places, so it helps to really know your stuff if you want to seem credible. The guy who wrote The Martian did a great job of portraying the planet based on our current scientific knowledge. I’m an astronomy buff, so I was pleased to see he got things right. If he’d made mistakes describing Mars, I might have put the book down.Read books about how to write a novel. I don’t think I can mention any here without running afoul of the site’s rules, but there’s a very valuable one about how to write a novel in 30 days that’s by far the best I read. I’m sure you can easily find it. That book had advice that really resonated with me, which is, make sure your novel keeps the reader hooked. You can make mistakes with character development, grammar, plot twists, etc. and get away with them. But if you can’t keep readers turning the pages to see what comes next, you won’t get anywhere.For beginning writers, it’s best to write about times and locales with which you have some familiarity. I’m a lifelong Chicagoan, so I placed part of my book in Chicago, which helps give those scenes authenticity and local flavor (hopefully). For scenes in Afghanistan or New York, I did some research to try and make them seem true. Whether I succeeded is anybody’s guess.The best advice for the actual writing process is to commit some time to it every day. Sit down and just tell yourself you’re going to spend the next hour writing. As you go along, day after day, it sometimes helps to revisit whatever you wrote the day before, read it and edit it, and then go from there. Doing so can jump-start your brain and help you get into the writing mode. It also can give you ideas for the plot, because you may see threads that weren’t evident for some reason in your previous writing session. Also, consider getting out of the house and writing somewhere far from work/family distractions. I wrote the majority of my book at the local coffee shop.Don’t skip a day, if at all possible. You’ll lose your rhythm. Commit to writing 1,000 words to 1,500 words a day, and hold off on something you enjoy (a snack, maybe, or a TV show), until you get it done.Anyone starting a novel benefits from having previous writing experience, even in non-fiction. I happen to be a journalist who’s written for a living for nearly 25 years, so writing came naturally to me, though fiction writing is very different than non-fiction and I had a steep learning curve. Write whenever you can, even if it’s a blog or online book reviews. Quora is an excellent place to give your writing muscles a workout, as well.The first novel you write is likely to end up, like mine, in that proverbial desk drawer (or computer file), but the process of writing it is invaluable and will put you on the road toward success the second or third time. Devote yourself to the process and don’t quit.

Apart from 'just start writing', which is good and common advice. Try to have more of a plot before hand, research what goes into a basic 'three act model' as a good starting point. Now some writers are what's termed 'pantsers' they 'fly by the seat of their pants'. They just start writing and see where the story goes, most pantsers will also acknowledge this makes for a longer editing process after the first draft. So the choice is up to you, there's nothing wrong with being a pantser or a plotter. Personally, after having done a stint at 'pantsing' for my first novel, I like to start with a brief outline of where my plot will go. I also like to write a synopsis before I start writing. This is an outline of what happens in the story, as if you were asked to condense the whole book into a few pages. I like to do this because reading it out or even sharing with other writers helps me notice the really big plot problems before I start writing tens of thousands of words. Once this is done I start writing the first draft. When you really get the hang of writing, you'll be able to finish a book in a few drafts. But the first book is always the hardest, so hang in there! If all else fails, this quote from number one selling novelist Nora Roberts helps me, "You can't edit a blank page." So write, even if you know it's rubbish. The beauty of writing is it can all be changed at a later point. The more you write, the more you'll develop a system that works for you and the better you get at it (though writing can never be called easy). When you're done with all of this and have a first draft in your hnads, ask us again how to edit––that is a whole other story. :)

When I started writing, I had no idea what to write. I sat for hours staring balnkly at my laptop screen, I had a strong urge to write something, but I didn't know the 'what' and the 'how'. I wrote and I deleted. Sometimes, the sentence formations were not correct, other times I felt I wasn't able to express what I wanted to convey. Days passed and I was still stuck. Then, I summoned google to my rescue. I asked, how can I start writing? I read number of related articles and there were a few things that all of them had in common: Just write. Whatever you can, however you can. Start it. Find a peaceful corner (your room, balcony, terrace, garden, anywhere where you are all by yourself) and just get things out of your head, pour it down on that blank page, imagine a situation in your mind, get into the character and let the words flow. Set a target for a day, and write everyday. Also, when you write, isolate yourself from the rest of the world, keep your phone aside, switch off the internet on your laptop. Dedicate the assigned time just for writing and getting things out of your head. And, you'll come up with something. Work on the sentence formations later on, when you've completed the draft. When you are just not able to write, take a break. Spend time in reading. You never know when something you read rings an alarm in you head and clears the blockage. Lastly, be patient. Rome was not built in a day. This quote always inspires me to write:  Every writer faces a similar situation, just have the audacity to never give up.

There are many methods favoured by different writers but nothing should ever be set in stone because writing is so subjective. Among the many ways described by tutors, the one I’d favour (personally) is a building model: First, you have your idea, so you’ll write that down and come up with a synopsis: the whole story on a page or two (this is one of the things an agent or publisher will ask for). Then a chapter plan: A bullet point list of chapters and what will happen in each. You might also have a brief biography of each of your characters. Most important though is the actual novel (obviously), which ought to be easier to write piecemeal with the first two stages complete. When it comes to writing the novel itself, my personal preference is to start at the beginning (some writers don’t) and let the narrative dictate. I’ve already written the ending in my head, so I know what I’m aiming for and roughly when. Using my novel Cyrus Song as an example, I knew I was going to need 20+ chapters, which turned out to be a 400pp book. Top tips: Make sure you include all that you wanted to from that bullet point chapter list you made. And keep an eye on dates and chronology: know what day you’re in when you’re writing. Above all, enjoy writing. The last thing it should be is stressful. Chill out and you’ll write a better book. Get friends to read bits you’ve written and give you feedback, but beware sycophants. Join online groups and forums, get to know other writers and ask them for advice as you’re going along. Don’t aim too high. There are tens of thousands of us writers, very few of whom will make a living from what we do. Most of us do it for personal enjoyment (and some of us for therapy), and knowing that we’ve written something which will survive long after us. Good luck and have fun :)

‘How should I start novel writing?’ It depends why you want to start a novel. Is it the money? You have a slight chance of being the next Rowling or King or Dickens. But in all honesty, you have more chance of winning the lottery. Or of being knocked down in the street by Lord Lucan, riding Shergar. [*] However, you’re entering the field at an interesting time. There used to be three broad descriptions of fiction writer. (1) For hire — you’re the one they go to when they want a novelisation of a famous TV series, delivered on time. (2) The mid-list — you never make a million, but you can hope to make as good a living wage as elsewhere; enough to keep you in socks and pay the mortgage. (3) The bestseller — people will buy your shopping lists, never mind your books, and pay gold for them. Then… this is a very broad-brush description, you understand — the publishing industry, for reasons way too complex to go into, decided to model itself on selling cans of baked beans. Instead of leaving books in print to gather support by word of mouth — and we know how important that is for sales — they gave them a short time to sink or swim, and put them out of print. Or moderate sales over a long period were no longer good enough; everybody had to be a bestseller. If those cans don’t move off the shelf, people don’t want those beans! Given that there are novels which will appeal to moderate sized groups of people, and continue to do so for generations, without ever being bestsellers… well, those got deep-sixed, as you might imagine. And now we come to modern publishing, in which self-publishing has ceased to be what it was once called — “vanity publishing” — but has become a solid way to start a career. I’m not certain it’s a way to start a career that’ll pay your mortgage, and I’m not sure if it’s the revenant mid-list. However, it is the way things are heading. Unfortunately, it also means that traditional publishing can now pay authors much less than they once would have done, for work of a quality which should deserve a living wage. And the problem with that, you say? Is that you get a lot more people having to write in “hobby time”, while they earn a living at another job. Which is not fine. There are certain kinds of concentration which require writing novels to be your main occupation. This is why, in Britain, there is a long tradition of novels being written by people of a certain class, who either had, or were married to, an independent income. Try Virginia Woolf’s essay, A Room of One's Own, where she says that “a woman must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction”. A room, that other people can’t come into and demand her time. And money, which purchases that time. (A man must have them too, but they’re still easier for him to get, just about.) If that hasn’t put you off starting a novel… good! You shouldn’t start writing a novel by thinking about money. I know a few people who do, but the vast majority of writers I ever met wanted to write a novel because they loved writing. Well, maybe not the actual writing. Having written, that’s very good. You’ve wrestled the many-tentacled beast of a story into a form of words, and you feel the satisfaction of victory. A few quick questions. Do you read a lot?Do you fantasise a lot — by which I mean, do you tell yourself stories?Do you love words? (Words as opposed to pictures, words as opposed to sounds.)When somebody asks ‘why do you want to write a novel?’, is your answer something along the lines of ‘…because? (implied duh!)’Have you already written something, or snippets of something, but you’re ashamed to admit to it?Or you have this idea that, if you could just put it down on paper…Because unless you love words and stories, and it’s self-evident to you that they — and producing them — are a satisfying thing to do… You might want to ask yourself if novels are exactly what you want to do. Assuming your answer is ‘yes’ to many/any of the above… You can start by writing, you can start by planning, you can start by staring out of the window and muttering lines of dialogue to yourself. All that matters is that you start, not how you start. Here’s one possible way: If you ‘don’t have any ideas’, as some people say, start your writing day with a pen and paper, and — without stopping to think — write down words for 30 minutes. It doesn’t matter if you spend two pages writing I have no ideas. Or fuck this for a game of soldiers! If you free-associate long enough, you’re likely to come up with something that tells you what’s on your mind. Maybe a memory from when you were six. Maybe something on the morning news. And then you can spend a few hours asking what if?, seeing if there’s a story idea in it. If you keep this up for days and weeks, don’t be surprised if you produce paragraphs that could be the start or end of a story. They won’t all be something you’ll want to write. But you will have accessed that part of you that has Ideas. Why do I say write with a pen? (Or pencil, I’m not picky.) I feel it has a different effect on the creative process. And before you say bollocks!, there are some differences noted — this references a study that students writing lecture notes with a pen get better results than those typing the notes: “they [the students writing in longhand] took fewer notes overall with less verbatim recording, but they nevertheless did better on both factual learning and higher-order conceptual learning.” Ink on Paper: Some Notes on Note Taking* I’m not aware of any studies on creative writing versus creative typing, but just from personal experience, I feel it’s something to try. There can be an amount of processing, I suppose you’d call it, that goes on between nib and page, that doesn’t between key and screen. And if it turns out not to be the case for you, you can always go back to typing! I hope some of this helps you.  [*] Google it. I’m not explaining an old-timer’s jokes. :)  Tl;dr — when anybody tells you there’s one thing you have to do, remember Kipling: "There are nine and sixty ways of constructing tribal lays, "And every single one of them is right!" Only for god’s sake don’t do it for the money…

It depends solely on what kind of writer you are. There are, basically, two kinds: The planner And The improviser… or the pantser… If you’re more of a planning kind of person then write out your plot using The Triangle: You draw a triangle (WHO NU????? =P)You label the first corner A or 1; the tip-top B or 2; and the last corner C or 3.A (or 1) is the beginning. This is where the story starts (i.e. girl meets boy).B (or 2) is where the action is at it’s highest (i.e. girl loves boy and confesses… what happens next???)C (or 3) is where the story ends (or, the falling action) (i.e. girl and boy get married). If you really want to get technical (like I do lol) then you can have A, A1, B, B1, and C. You could go throw all the numbers and just label them as key plot points/twists/etc.You then break your plot down into the bare minimum (take away all sub-plots and plot twists) of three. The beginning, the climax of the story, and the end. Then, once you have that, add in your plot twists, sub-plots, sub-stories, etc, etc.And voila! you have your plot planned out neatly; then you can jump into character sketches and writing. If you are more of a pantser and prefer to write before planning (mainly to get the feel of the story) then this is what you can do: Write. Just write at whatever part of the story intrigues you most. Write until you hit a point where you need to plot plan with The Triangle.Then, after you hit that point, go ahead and complete The Triangle.Then go back to writing or to character sketches (character sketches are MANDATORY for awesome, consistent characters!)Honestly, it will take you a long time to write a novel, I have been writing one story for almost a year and it’s still a novella. If you aim small, you’ll get the big stuff in the end. If you write a basic fifty page story from start to finish (really, that is nothing - fifty pages is hardly any time to get into the story) then after editing you’ll have seventy-five, then’ll you’ll notice what characters need more developmental processes, what events need more lead up, what plot-points need more time, and then you’ll have 150 pages. Don’t expect to have a novella in three months (unless writing is your full-time job lol), and don’t expect perfection right away… because you’ll be disappointed. Good luck with your writing! And may it take flight and fly to beautiful, beautiful places!

I recommend outlining the plot. It may not work for you (everybody is different) but I close my eyes and try to visualize a scene from my novel like a scene from a movie. I even “cast” my characters with the same actors I would like to play them in the movie adaptation of my novel. Every item in my outline becomes a chapter in the story. The easiest entries on the outline are the necessary steps the hero has to take to reach the conclusion. Then we must add the false steps and red herrings, because unless our hero is God, he or she can’t be omniscient. It’s like drawing a road map for your story. Basically I start with an idea…what action has motivated my main character to do what I plan for him or her to do? My novels typically begin with some action (usually a murder, or some other criminal activity) and the end is always the final resolution in a climatic scene, usually a showdown with the villain of the piece. But in between is the art of connecting the dots…how does our hero become involved in the story, and how does he or she bring about this resolution? We not only need a compelling and plausible explanation for how we reached our conclusion, we need to show how our protagonist got there, both metaphorically and literally speaking. We need to create that trail of breadcrumbs that leads us from the witch’s house in the forest to safety, the birds that eat those breadcrumbs and spoil our best plans, and then some clever twist or action that gets us to our happy ending, unless our story doesn’t have a happy ending. But we still need to have some idea for how the story ends before we begin trying to tell it. Even if we decide to change the ending…the point is to have a destination in mind when you begin to tell the story. In the novel I’ve been developing, initially the resolution was going to kill off several characters, according to the first outline. But now the plot has changed to the point where the conflict is resolved without a major bloodbath, because it all works. The outline can be changed. But I have to have some idea of where I’m going before I get started, or I’ll get lost in my own plot.

You answered your own question. Start writing. Now. Ian Fleming wrote Dr. No in one month while typing away in his home in Jamaica. One month. 4 weeks. Didn't re-write a word. That's inspiration for you. Don't anticipate the end. Let the story take you there. That's what Stephen King likes to do. He enjoys writing the book as much as his readers do reading it. He likes to be surprised where it's taking him. It's why he cranks out so many best sellers. He's enjoying the journey as much as his readers are. Most writers do much the same. So get onboard, fasten your seat belt, and let the writing fly the plane. That's why I enjoy writing. On the other hand, former crime beat reporters like Michael Connelly and John Sandford know their subjects well which is police procedure and the judiciary system. It makes their Harry Bosch and Lucas Davenport novels so authentic. You don't have to write what you know and you're certainly not chained by the old “show not tell” adage. Many bestsellers don't follow that advice at all. Dialogue should be just as people speak, not how your grammar school teacher instructed you how to speak. People often don't speak in complete sentences. They speak in contractions. They volley back and forth during conversations. Here's a hint. Use, “said” more often such as, “What business are you in”, he said, rather than, “he asked”. For any kind of statement, “said” is better than describing how he felt making the statement.

One way to start would be to collect pictures out of old magazines that look like people you want to put in your book, collect pictures of places that look like places you want to put in your book. Then you could start to write about those people and those places. Once you've sketched out those, write about links between the people, and write scenes placing your people in those places. That'll get you started. You could also start with "I want to write a novel but I do not know where to start." And then explain why you want to write a novel, what you want it to be about--what and who and where; why what, why who, why where. Explain how you intend to write the novel, how long it will take, how many pages, how many pages a week, how many drafts, how you will know when it is done, and how you will market it when you are done.

An outline of how you want the book to progress is a good place to start. What is the timeline of this book? How long will it take for the main character(s) to get from point A (the beginning) to point B (the end)? Where is your book going to start? Who is there? Why are these first characters important to the timeline of your book and character(s) development? What is your rising action? What happens that sets the story into motion and leads to the climax? What is the climax of your story? This is the most exciting part of the book. It’s usually the point where the main character(s) needs to make an important decision that will determine how the book will end. Up next is the falling action. Things are winding down. All of the major decisions have been made and you’re tying up loose ends. Finally, the conclusion. The ending. What did your character(s) learn? How did they change? Character outlines can also be helpful. This is where you write down all of your character(s) personality traits, flaws, physical appearance, psychology, and history. Knowing who a person is before you begin writing can help a lot as your story develops. You’ll be able to better understand how your character would react to certain situations.

First, complete the whole main story in your head. Start by writing plot outlines on a piece of paper, in pairs, one by one. If the story is not yet completed in your head, do not start writing. There must be a core story in order to start writing a novel. The main story has to be finished in your head. What do I want to write about? Who will I be writing about? Where and when? Even, why do I write? Everything that goes into it. No more doubts along the way, apart from the regular adjustments you’ll certainly have to make. Only then the by-plots can jump in. You can either choose to write the story backwards or constructive, i.e. from the beginning. It is recommended to do what you think is best for you. You’re building on a story yourself and you have all the time to come up with the best story of all time. To write the all-consuming novel/book. At least, that’s how I reason. Each time you write, work at the same time of the day. Pick your moment to write. Follow your instincts. Do not model yourself after another person. Try to be unique, tell your own story. Let your own emotions be your driver. Especially as a writer. Lock yourself from the outside world and work hard on creating a personal image. Where people recognize you from, is what I mean, e.g. the stylistic elements you like to use. It’s very simple to discover yourself while writing. In short, you should write a lot. Write until you won’t utter a sound. And read, read, read, of course. It makes you wiser. Books make you a wise man. Read as much novels and other fiction as you possibly can, however, only write when you’re fully ready. I can give you tips, we can all give you tips, I suppose. But maybe you shouldn’t have read these tips, since writing is this long road of finding your own way. I guess I can only tell you where to begin. Happy writing! Peace.

Start writing. At this point, over 100 people have answered this question. If you are still reading answers, what are you waiting for? Every New Year, people resolve that this will be the year they lose weight and get in shape. Many of them get bogged down in the details: should I lift weights or do cardio? Yoga or Pilates? Eat a low-carb or low-fat diet? Paleo or keto? At some point, you just need to move more and eat less. If you stay consistent, you’ll see results and you can adjust your routine to fit your goals. And if you want to write a novel, you need to pick an approach, get in front of your computer or pull out your notebook, and get to work.  “But what if I take the wrong approach?” you might ask. “What if I start down one path and it turns out not to be the right one?” A. You’re better off picking the wrong path than picking no path at all.If you want to be an author, you’re better off writing a bad novel and having the opportunity to learn from your mistakes than writing nothing at all. B. Even if you do pick the wrong path, all is not lost.I’ve written a novel where I outlined an entire scene in painstaking detail, wrote the scene, tore it up, and outlined and wrote it again. And I’m currently writing a novel where I wrote almost all the scenes in the story first, then went back and put them in the right order. Nothing is irreversible when it comes to writing. Every writer has a different style. And lots of people have shared great ideas for writing styles on this thread. The only way to find out what works for you is to pick an approach that looks good and go for it. The only way to write a novel is to write it.

I start with a character, in a setting, with a problem. I introduce these three elements in any order to hook the reader. Then I have the character try to solve the problem. When I start I have a good idea of the charter/setting/problem, and some idea of the final resolution of the problem (climax of the story). The hard part is solving the problem (the plot). I usually do a brief outline. The protagonist needs to try to solve the problem and fail. This makes the problem worse. He/she needs to gather their resources and try again…and fail. This makes the problem a matter of life and death. Now the character needs to gather what resources are left and try on last desperate time to solve the problem. If they succeed you have a happy climax. If they fail you have a tragic climax. The outline keeps me on point as I work my charter through the middle of the story, and keeps me from letting him/her wonder up blind alleys. If you WANT to write a novel, you must have some kind of an idea. Create a character that would be faced with the problem you imagine and put him/her in a setting. Start by writing the opening scene of your novel introducing these elements.

Well, it depends on how early you are in the process. If you don’t have a concept yet, if you don’t have a premise, then you’ll want to spend some time thinking about what interests you. Consider a time and place that you know well. If it’s your first novel, that time and place will probably end up being your setting, just because we tend to write what we know, and the places we know best make the best, most detailed settings. Then, consider the people that pique your curiosity. What makes them interesting to you? Maybe you’re fascinated by greed, or betrayal, or addiction, or codependency, or delusion, or aggression, or gullibility. Whatever the thing is that fascinates you, that will probably be the guiding character trait of at least one of your main characters. As those character traits emerge, the characters will follow. And when the characters emerge, you’ll start to see a connection between them. And in that connection, you’ll start to find some conflict. When you’ve got your conflict, you’ll have the beginnings of a plot.

There are as many ways to write a novel as there are writers. But all their methods seem to fall into one of two categories. So you decide which works for you, then you simply go for it. The first category consists of ‘pantsers’, writers who write by the seat of their pants. They simply sit down at a computer and start writing whatever comes into their minds. Then, later, they put all those words into some sort of order.The second category consists of ‘plotters,’ writers who create an outline of their story from beginning to end and then follow their outline, writing something about each part of it until they reach the end.Of course, nothing is truly that simple, but either way is a good way to start and, once you’ve started, the rest will fall into place if you check out books on the craft of writing fiction or take some classes to teach you how to deal with the parts that you have trouble with after writing that first draft as either a ‘pantser’ or a ‘plotter.’

Primarily, you must know the characteristics of novel as a genre of writing fiction. Read the following first: The defining characteristics of the novel genre include a long, fictional story comprised of characters, events and actions that have a definite beginning and an eventual end. The novel genre has several sub-categories that include historical novels, mystery novels and romance novels. Novels are stand-alone books or books that are part of a series of novels The main characteristic that all types of novels share is that they are written to entertain their readers. Novelists -- people who write novels -- use forward-moving plots to engage their readers' attention and make them care about the well-being and fate of the main character or group of main characters throughout the book. The novel genre is based upon the suspension of disbelief that a reader must invoke to immerse herself in the book. In other words, since novels are not real, the reader must accept the fictional story as plausible in order to remain engrossed in the story. Novelists keep their readers engaged by creating characters, places, things and events that mimic real life or fantasy situations that appeal to a specific demographic. For example, romance novels mainly appeal to women readers, while historical novels appeal to people who are inherently drawn to the past. Learning it seriously, you read novels of great writers as much as possible. When you will grab all things you will learn yourself that writing novel is not an easy task. However, you should start with writing with short stories.

First of all, I’m glad that you’re interested in writing a novel. It is rewarding and you’re going to love how you feel when you finally hold that final copy in your hands. But, I’m getting ahead of myself. Before starting any kind of writing, you’ll want to have the right tools and basic knowledge. You’ve done well by coming up with an idea and plot for your novel. Now, backtrack just a little and ask yourself, “how is my grammar? Spelling? Punctuation?” Yes, you will eventually hire an editor, but you need to be able to form basic sentences and paragraphs correctly (which I’m going to guess that you already do). If not, you can use resources such as Khan Academy and Alison to refresh your skills. They offer free grammar and language courses that are perfect for this. Once you have a solid language foundation, you’ll want to look at your chosen genre and find out what additional training you may need. It is possible for you to simply dive in and start writing at this point, but you will do a much better job with your manuscript if you know about the mechanics of writing in a particular genre. I had a client who writes science fiction and editing the manuscript was nothing short of torture for me! In that particular case, I was only asked to proofread and perform light editing, so that’s what I did. In reality, it needed a complete overhaul. The author meant well, but the manuscript read more like a mashup of sci-fi and action movies spanning the last 20 years. The worlds, characters, and technology were not properly constructed, making the whole novel harder to follow than it needed to be. You can avoid that mistake by taking specific courses (or doing online research) on how to set up various kind of novels (romance, murder, thriller, mystery, sci-fi, etc). They all tend to have their own set of techniques. Once you feel confident that you have the fundamentals of language as well as genre-specific conventions for plot, dialogue, characters, setting, flow, and so on, you should be good to go to begin the fun part - writing!

I’ve seen a lot of good answers here, but everyone’s process is different. So, now I will contradict every other answer I’ve seen on this thread. I don’t write 100 or 500 words per day. I could never make myself do that. For me, writing is spontaneous and when it happens it happens (for pages and pages) and when it doesn’t, it doesn’t. That may change as I get older, especially if it becomes one of my main demands in life, but for now, that’s the way it is. Forcing myself to write every day is too methodical and it feels wrong. Writing is not my profession yet. Though I’d like it to be one day, I don’t have to treat it that way now— not if my muse would rather bounce around with its head in the clouds and then fall asleep. I don’t plan out entire books before writing them, either. I don’t know where they’re going to go, and trying to plan the whole thing out when so much of it doesn’t exist yet is, again, forcing it. A story is more than just plot. Characters write the story, conflicts spring up on their own, and the plot shifts as it goes along. I wish I were a little better at planning plots, but I write books the same way I write essays— start with the first word, end with the last. Everything else is worked out in between. It’s not easy, but it’s the method that works best for me. Believe me, I’ve tried outlines before. That hasn’t gone well. The only time I do outline a book is when I’ve already written it once, so I already have an idea of what I’d like the plot to be and I just need to arrange it in a way that makes sense. I don’t start at the end and work backwards, either. Though sometimes I wish I could do that, the very idea of it makes my head spin. Transitions, anyone? I don’t worry about finishing, either. Some projects I abandon after a while. Some take a lot of revision before they’ve even gone anywhere. I had one novel that I realized I couldn’t finish with the narration pattern I was using, and now I’ve started it all over from the beginning and I don’t regret it. Now I feel like I’m doing something wrong. That I’m wasting time. That if I actually tried writing every day, it wouldn’t always be utter crap. That I should write first and then revise (which makes the task seem so much more monumental, daunting, and overwhelming than it already is). That writing should not be erratic or spontaneous or no work would ever get done— except, it does. At some point, even if it takes a few years, I end up with a 200+ page novel and I wonder, “How did that happen?” Of course, I’ve come to the same conclusion that everyone else has— just write. Just start. Starting is not the hard part. The best way to start writing a novel is just to WRITE. There’s nothing else to it. Put your ideas down on paper and see where they go. The rest— technique, character development, worldbuilding, revision, editing, emotional turmoil— comes later. You were talking about starting. But, be aware that your writing process will be unique and you should write in a way that works for you.

Here are my suggestions:  Have an idea -- Even if it is a small one, have some idea of what you want to write about.Let that idea grow -- I always recommend sitting down and writing down at least a small plan of what you want to do with your idea. Anywhere from a short synopsis to a detailed outline. Write -- This seems obvious but you'd be amazed how stuck you can get on the "planning" stage that you don't get to the writing stage. Try to set a specific time during the day where you devote to just writing and make sure you limit the distractions (turn off the internet, tell people to not interrupt, turn off your phone, etc.) to the best of your ability (as a parent I find it can be hard to do that, but it is workable).Read -- Both in your genre and out of it. Find time to read and look at what makes you enjoy the stories. Once  you know what you like to read, you'll be able to find ways of putting that same technique into your own writing. Also, read trade books on the process of writing, publishing and other writing topics.Find a critique/writing group -- Once you get a decent amount of something written, you'll want to have an unbiased eye (not a spouse of family member) look over the piece and give  you honest feedback. Make sure you find people you trust and make sure they give you just as much good feedback as bad. Even better is a person who can give you the "don't likes" followed by a "here is what I think would make it better".Take workshops or classes -- Continue to learn. Those are six things I recommend doing to get started. Once you have a good start on that (and a finished product) then you will be getting into things like editing (which I don't recommend doing until after your first draft is done -- get your words out!) and querying.  Good luck on your writing!

I'm going to focus on your question, which was how you get STARTED, not how do you write a complete novel. (Most of the advice in the other posts are so much water on your creative fire, as I see it.) Start by writing a short story, 5000 words. In the short story you will create some characters. When you are finished with the story, write some biographical sketches of your characters. 2000 words or more for each. At least 5 sketches. Then write another story using these same characters, 5000 words. By now you have some places, some settings. Bring them to life. Describe them in minutiae. 2000 word minimum per place. 5 settings. Write another story using the same places. Let it sit for at least a month, preferably longer. Start cutting and pasting. By now you should have the makings of 1/3 of a novel at least. That's a start. Filling in gaps should double the wordcount. Where you go from there is up to you.

The sentence might be “I have four things in my life that bug me.” I can make a short page of a story out of that. Anything that intrigues me as a starting ignition point is what I need. Four things. Outline the plot. Beginning, where we get to meet your character. Inciting Incident. Where we know the obstacle that makes the hero move. Consequences. Response. Stakes get higher. Etc.Have some idea of the ending. It doesn’t matter if you change it later. But it’s easier to start a journey if you know where you’re going.Commit. Put a deadline to it. Not necessarily the whole novel, but start with putting deadlines to chapters. Write everyday. It doesn’t matter if it’s crap. It doesn’t matter if you write chapters or plot lines you think you’re not gonna use. Don’t delete anything. You never know what will become useful.Don’t worry about order. Some writers need to write their novel in order. I admire the discipline, but if you thought about something cool for the last third of your novel, write it. Figure out how to connect it later.

PLOT the book. It’s so much easier to finish if you know where you’re going.Don’t edit! Push through, writing a quick rough scene sketch, until you reach the conclusion. Go back and reorganize and improve scenes until everything is in the right place.Once everything is in the right place and your story is awesome, start fixing the writing - better dialogue, better character motivation, better first and last sentences to every chapter, and adding scene and setting description (readers forget words, they remember images - put pictures in their heads.)Know your readership: make sure you know who will be reading your book, what kind of books they like and WHY they like them (research top 10 bestselling books in your genre and read all the reviews). Make sure your story has similar elements and will satisfy those readers in a similar way - but be new and different enough for them to enjoy it.

Try a pen and paper… The best way to start writing anything is simply to start. Depending on the type of novel you're writing, the ideas would either develop as you go along or the characters will take on a life and personality of their own. Don't worry about writers block. It happens to the best of us. When you get stuck, just step back, take some time off from writing and allow the story to run its natural course. Something will reinspire you and your work will come back to life. If you're a really busy person and you find you're having difficulty planning and making time to write, I'd suggest you take s few minutes before you go to sleep, or just as you wake up, to write. You can't really write a masterpiece overnight… well it's possible, but judging by the nature of the question, I'd say give your work time, give your ideas time to mature. You may have a great idea but giving it that time to cook will make it an international bestseller. Read a lot. The more you have, the more you have to give. Your story has more substance and becomes more realistic when you have a wider range of knowledge and are able to translate that into your writing. Also, you'll find that the more you read, the more you pick up styles of other authors. You can tell J. K. Rowling read a lot of Lord of the Rings simply by her ideas and style of writing. Be innovative, be yourself. Your novel isn't your novel without a bit of you in it. If you have no passion for it, you'll struggle to put a bit of yourself into it. Writing is as difficult as any other profession, it takes passion, commitment and a hell of a lot of perseverance. It takes becoming vulnerable at times, exposing yourself to the world in a way no one else has ever seen you. It also takes strength, to keep walking when you can't run, limping when you can't walk and crawling when you can't move, but in all of that, never stopping, always moving forward. I'd like to wish you all the best in writing your novel (that's if you are gonna write one). Remember that your words are eternal and your books are your legacy, so make sure it's not just a good one, it's a great one.

If you’re a new writer, then something makes you want to write. Whatever that is, let it get you through your first story. That is very person and particular, so it’s hard to give advice about. But I can give some more general writing advice: Don’t just jump into a novel. Remember that short stories can do as much work as novels with fewer words.Writing is an art – remember that. So, whatever you have a question about (unless it’s grammar or something governed by an important linguistic rule) likely has two or three correct answers. Feel free to explore your options.Read! Writers read. I’ve typed this countless times – and it’s true. The more you read, the more effectively you will write.Good luck with writing. Feel free to message me if you ever need help.

Yes there is a little known but often used trick for writing a novel. Write or type a word. Then follow it with another word. Keep adding words until you have a sentence. Once you’ve accomplished that, start another sentence and perhaps another until you have a paragraph. Now rinse and repeat. That’s all there is to getting started. One word after another. Then comes the hard part. You need to start editing and/or rewriting those words until they start to resemble a story. Then you need to work them over even more until they resemble a story someone may actually want to read. Throw away all the words that don’t work to further the story and keep the ones that do. Here is one magic tip. Read a lot and write a lot. That’s it. The first million words is for practice. If you keep it up long enough you have a chance at success.

You know, I see all these questions asking for “tips, tricks or hacks” to get started on writing something. Reality check time: writing fiction is not the same as making hash browns in a waffle iron. There are no shortcuts, no tricks, no tips and no hacks. If you want to write, you write. There is no other way. You glue your ass to the chair and you write. It doesn’t matter if what you write is crap; in fact, if you have never written fiction before it will be crap, because you have no practice at it. You get better by writing a lot. You can’t edit or improve something that isn’t there in the first place.

In a word, yes, you should just write. If you need to take a course, go ahead. But what determines a writer is not whether or not the person takes, or has taken, what courses, gone through what courses of study or anything else of the sort. It’s whether or not you write. I’ve never taken a creative writing course in my life. I doubt I could hold still for one, especially when I consider some of the things I get to edit. Once you’ve begun to write and actually turned out some finished works, then you can decide whether to take courses and hone your skills that way or not. You may be able to improve by doing it and listening to your beta readers - someone out there will read what you wrote and critique it, even if you have to pay them to do it - and eventually, your editors. But if you want to write, write. If you want to study writing, go ahead - but know that it won’t make you a writer. At most, it will make you a more-educated wannabe writer. Only writing will make you a writer. So go ahead. Put pen to paper, or fingers to the keyboard, or whatever method turns your crank, but write. Hey - I had my first five pages written before I ever experienced writer’s block.

Most books suggest starting with an outline. But I can’t do it that way even though it would save me lots of rewriting.	For my first draft I set of goal of 1667 words a day. This is suggested by Nanowrmo, National Novel Writing month.While this is celebrated in November, you can write a book ay month. Staying close to your suggested word count every day gets you 50,000 words in  thirty days. Novels are usually between 80,000 and 90,000 words, so your story will need to be fleshed out, but you now have a skeleton. 	Next comes the revisions. Expect to read and reread, and revise and revise.	Keep track of characters by having index cards with birth date,  color hair, eyes, hobbies, quirks, and important events like marriages. Decide what is important to each character.	Do the same with scenes.What happens in each scene? How does this move the story along?	Have a time line, even if your story happens in just 24 hours.

Some people plan in minute detail. Other people wing it and make the story up as they go along. Stephen King has said he has no idea how a story will end when he starts it. I tend to have key plot points in mind. The twists, the “what if…?” type of things that I want to explore in a story. Sometimes, you don’t know how a story starts. So start somewhere else. Instead of Chapter 1. Start in the middle of a scene that you really feel. Something that brings the characters, the conflict, the plot to life for you. No one else will read it until the book is finished anyway. I think it is the same with film making - they don’t make the opening credits, the first scene and so on in linear order - the filming jumps all over the place and gets edited together before it is finished. Writing can be like that too. Once you have more experience and confidence, you can start at the beginning - but never forget it is okay to write how you want (pantser, plotter, linear or more selectively).

Type, “Chapter One.” There are no rules, and there is no formula. You need to sit down and write the story. If you think an outline would make it easier, write an outline — and don’t worry too much about following it. If you want to start at the beginning, that’s pretty standard, but you can start in the middle, or you can write the ending first — those have both been done successfully. To quote Rudyard Kipling: “There are nine and sixty ways Of constructing tribal lays And every single one of them is right.” Do whatever works for you. If you’ve never heard of anyone else working that way, that doesn’t mean you’re doing anything wrong, it means you’re an original. Just write. Stop thinking about it, stop talking about it, stop worrying about it — just do it.

Seize the passion as it crests, then worry about the details later. Write whatever, whenever, however much you want. That idea that's been tingling in the back of your brain for days? Scribble it down before it becomes unattainably buried in the trenches of your brain. An outline may be beneficial, if you have a thoughtful, cohesive plan. But otherwise, it's often nice to just transform your thoughts into word and vomit them all over the page. Order will follow later. If your gut tells you to begin with thorough, extensive research, start with that. If your gut tells you to furiously smash on the computer keys until you have some semblance of a story, start with that. Novel writing is a wonderful experience because you have immense flexibility, and the beginning is the best place to let wild imagination fly free.

Come up with a place, a time, a character, and a situation faced by the character. Proceed from there, and don't stop until you've reached the end. Perhaps your story will be long enough to be called a "novel", perhaps not.  As you proceed, you'll probably get the feeling that what you're creating is stupid. Keep going anyway. The important thing is to finish it!  It's important to make your characters suffer and to make their suffering either kill them or force them to change. Put them through hell.  Create suspense by delaying the outcome of situations arising from the characters' fears and desires. Make sure that everything that happens is plausible within the logic of the world of your story. If you really want to write a novel, and if you have the time and the resources to support you while you write it, get busy and don't give up!

Start writing. I wrote hundreds of thousands of words and started ten novels before I finished my first one. The journey is long. I see you’ve told everyone your idea, that can be an idea killer not because someone might steal it but because once you’ve expressed the idea the urge to express it is gone. Be ready to write and rewrite it many times over. Take your first novel as a learning experience. Puking words out onto a page is easy. Writing something people will read is incredibly difficult. Read, read all the time. Make writing an every day habit. don’t be afraid to walk away and think about your story. Read Stephen King’s Dance Macabre and On Writing. The novel will happen on your journey to becoming a writer, all you need do currently is write until it does.

Gather inspiration from other novels or from media, past experiences, stories you've heard, or things that fascinate you. Carry a small notebook with you at all times and write down any words, sentences, or descriptions that come to mind. Have an idea of what genre you'd like your novel to be. Envision where your story will take place, as well as what the characters who will populate your novel will be like. Think of a central conflict and branch out your story from that issue. Make an outline and conduct any necessary research. Establish a writing routine that you can stick to on a regular basis, and create your first draft. Self-edit, share your work with a few others, and revise your draft until you feel satisfied with what you've created. Good luck with it. Best regards!

There are as many ways to write a novel as there are combinations of words that can form the content of that novel, but the most important thing to remember is that writing a novel is very similar to running a marathon. It will be a long haul, and it will take a lot of extra work beyond just the writing itself. Things like time management, perseverance, and good organizational skill can be incredibly helpful, while skills such as plotting and character development are an absolute necessity. So where should you start? You'll have to figure out what way works best for you, but for me the best start always comes in the form of outlining. I write a rough sketch of the overarching story, then I break that down into the pacing I want, and finally figure out what chapter sections I would want to keep at that pacing. This gives me a strong structural framework around which to write the story, and also makes it easier to write any part of the story as it comes to me rather than feeling trapped into having to write the chapters in the order they appear in the book.

Literary agents often tweet about what they are looking for.
