Start by writing- not just wanting to write. Write everyday and like playing tennis you’ll get better. Choose a subject you know and write about that - avoid guessing about how things are done in a field you are not familiar with. Read other novels and pay attention to voices( 1st, 2nd, 3rd person,etc). Look at genres at Wikipedia to know which genre your writing style and subject fits into.Try to write the book from beginning to end with all the research you need to be accurate with dates ect. before you do serious editing -otherwise you never get past the editing stage.Keep links or citations( if a book, video, movie for your research in case you need to go back and find it again. Don’t worry about the publishing aspect until you are done.( You will edit a lot more before your book is printed). Believe in yourself and your unique voice.

The first step is coming up with an idea for a plot. Once you have a plot, start a written outline for the story. At the very top of your outline, before you start laying out the chapters, try to write a summary of your story. (e.g. “A young man finds a dragon egg in the mountains and embarks on a dangerous journey to escape the evil emperor’s assassins”) Usually for me, the outline will look much like an outline for a research paper with bullet points acting as designations of each chapter and what happens in each one. It doesn’t have to be super-detailed, just detailed enough that you can know what it is you want happening in each segment. After that, it’s simply a matter of writing the actual chapters.

Start anywhere. I didn’t write for years because I didn’t know how to start. Then one day I read Diana Gabaldon’s website and her advice on writing. She doesn’t write from the beginning to the end. She writes one scene at a time and then strings them together. She writes what she sees. That made so much sense to me. I wrote a scene and then ended up jumping to the beginning and writing straight through. The main thing is to find what works for you. Some authors first write detailed histories of all their characters. Some authors write an outline. Some just dive in. Do it your way. You may even find that different books require different approaches. Bottom line is, writers write. And through experience they learn that a lot of the magic is in the rewriting.

Start at the end and work your way backwards. No wait, hold on, start in the middle and work your way out…oh hold on… Actually, if you have to ask that question, continue to read novels until you don’t have to ask that question. People will give you a variety of answers on how to get started, but the first thing to do is to read many novels yourself. You will start to get an idea of how to start your own, the more you read. Some people out there will encourage you to outline the novel first and plot it carefully. Others will tell you to just start writing, and you will “discover” how to write the novel. My answer is, do whatever works for you. This is your first novel, you might as well have fun, experiment, and learn what you like to do and don’t like to do.

My professor used to tell me the most important thing in writing a fiction work is to know how you want it to end. The reasoning is, if you don’t know the ending, you might just keep writing and never reach a conclusion. Therefore, the essential element is, knowing your ending. Besides that, just start writing. You have to start. Some people will talk to you about character development and the like. I look at writing like a relationship. The more time you spend with the person, the more you learn about them. Just get started.

Every writer has their own way of doing things, so there is no set formula. However, with your basic plot outline that is a good start. For me, I write the plot line down and then go back constantly to pad out the story. Some writers just sit down and keep writing until the end before going back to edit. I can't do this. It is a case of constant rereading and going back to add bits and take bits out. I also don't often know what I'm going to write before I write it. I sit down, begin to type, and the story just takes over. It is a constant revelation to me as I have no idea what I'm going to write that day. As I said, this is not the same for other writers. I'd suggest sitting down somewhere quiet and just starting to write. You never know what might come out! Good luck.

There are as many ways to write as there are writers. The important thing is to write. Do the action, don’t think about it. Inspiration comes from doing, not thinking. The more you write, the better you’ll get. Books and classes are good for support and advice, but only while you’re learning on the job. Remember that the first, second and twelfth drafts of your novel might be terrible. Early drafts are always terrible. Don’t judge yourself. Keep working on it. It will come together eventually. As a bipolar person, you have a creative advantage because your mind is far more interesting than most! The great Carrie Fisher was bipolar and a brilliant, extremely inventive writer. Her mind was an artistic motherlode.  Just keep at it no matter what. Use that gifted mind of yours and let your voice be heard.

As much as possible. It’s a useful skill for an author.Imagination. Let it run wild. If you have to ask the question, then you probably don’t have a novel bursting to be written. If you did, you would be writing it already. However, if you have written short stories, or other fiction, and feel the urge to write a novel then just go for it. There are no rules. You can start anywhere you like. For me, the characters are the most important. Build up believable people in your mind, give them some kind of conflict or problem to solve, and then go with the flow. For others, plot matters more - if you have a story in your mind, then start with that and gradually build up the characters involved. There are many books about writing novels, and thousands of relevant websites, but in the end it’s up to you whether to write a novel, and how to go about it.

You could try shaking up your imagination with a interesting first sentence. With that, not only will it be a hook for future readers, but it can jump-start the creative process for you, and you might decide to change the basic outline. I have no idea what your book is about, so I don't know if it's appropriate for this particular novel, but you could start with something like, "Andre was sick of all the running." This sets you up for a potentially action-packed, emotional, heart-driven novel. Try to find a opening sentence that you feel has a lot of potential, and then just start writing. Don't think about your outline, or if people will like it, or grammatical errors, those can all be fixed later. Just let your hand take control and see where it takes you when it's on autopilot. Good luck.

It depends on what kind of genre of book you want to make. But it also depends on how you like to start it. There are many authors and writers who would make many, many edits in the their novels so that the readers can understand and learn the story.You also need a plan on how you would like the story to play out. One of the most stressful things about writing is to find the inspiration and imagination to write the things that you want your characters to say, what they do, what they think. But don't stress to much, the idea will come to you sooner or later and you will know what to write.I hope this answer will help you. But if not, then just go ahead with the ideas of what you want to write in your novel and how to start it. Mix up some ideas like a blender and see what you came up with.

Just start writing down the plot, to begin with. Characters will suggest themselves as you do. Write down as much of the plot as you can, and jot notes for the characters as they occur to you. Just let it flow organically out of your mind and onto the paper/word-processor. Eventually, you’ll want to organize it, start adding scene and setting details, flesh out the characters. But as the saying goes: “Write what you know.” If what you know is the plot so far, then just start writing it down. Don’t worry about whether it’s good/bad/ugly/brilliant/stupid/etc, just write. They’ll be time enough for changing it later. The most important thing now is to capture what you’ve got.

It’s still a few months away but National Novel Writing Month. Go to the website (nanowrimo.org) and sign up. It’s a good way to just get some words out there. It is an annual challenge where writers all around the world get together and try to write 50 000 words in a month. I’ve done it for two years now and will be doing it again this year. depending on your area, there are community write ins hosted every day where you can meet with other writers and network. in my area, we have daily write ins attended by a minimum of 6–8 people, and some days we have upwards of 15–20. join your local region and see whats around. The key to write a novel is an Idea. Every great novel starts with a great idea. You need to have an idea, albeit a small one, but still an idea. You need to write something about that idea- anything related to it, about a page or two. Start jotting down ideas that come to your mind. Again, be it any dumb, silly idea, you NEED to jot it down, at that very moment, with anything you have -a pencil, a marker, even lipstick. I cannot stress enough on this point. Many brilliant ideas come at the most unexpected moments, and are forgotten within seconds. Trust me. Start weaving a web around the main idea-slowly at first, then, as the book starts building itself inside your mind in an amazing fashion, you need to pick up the pace. Happy writing!

You really don't have a plot in your head; you may have a thought but not a plot.Sit down and write your thoughts but not as a book; just your thoughts no matter how random. Now comes the hard part. Look hard at what you have written. Try to put the random thoughts in order even if you have to number them such as 1, 2, 3. Now you have the start of a plot. How did, more or less what led up to this point and what comes after. Answer these two points and now you have a plot. Now you can join the thousands and share their joys, sadness, sweat, and tears which comes from writing a book. Write the whole story from beginning to end as fastly as possible. Don't worry about it being good just get it all out. That's the key ingredient to create bestsellers.

First question, you need to ask yourself " Do you have a fully formed story in mind?" Second question, you need to ask yourself "Do I have the will and commitment to write 300 pages(or more)?" What you have to keep in mind is : It is a very time consuming and at times a frustrating commitment but at the end it would be worth it.You have to write everyday i.e. atleast 10 pages of your story.Your first aim is to make your story known to yourself first, finish the first draft as soon as possible regarding how raw or grammaricaly incorrect it might be (It is for your eyes only).As Stephen King once said " The scariest moment is just before you start and after it only gets better." Have faith in yourself and write on my friend.

Assuming it’s the first time you’re trying something like this: Just do it. However you start, however you go at it, the important thing is that you start. Even if it ends up being bad. And truth be told, it most likely will. Writing a book is so much harder than many think. Developing a good writing style takes time. Developing characterization, pacing, structure, it all takes several failed attempts. Even if the finished product ends up being bad, you’ll have learned a lot with it. By the time you reach the end, you’ll already be much better than you were at the beginning. Then, you can go back and rewrite the first chapters and edit the rest, and you’ll have a finished book and a lot of experience. Now, that book most likely still won’t be of the quality needed to publish it, but, according to my experience, your second book just might.

Great question. A novel is going to require dedication and perseverance. Most writers suggest you OUTLINE your story before you start. Roughly . . . what is the main character trying to accomplish and what are the struggles that they endure as they strive to reach their goal? When planning your story’s structure, start with this no-fail method: Create a Doorway of No Return for your protagonist before the 1/5 mark of your book. Is he happy, sad, excited, hopeful, afraid? SHOW that emotion by his body language, his words, his facial expression.
